commit_message:
Move rabbit option settings from DEFAULT to oslo_messaging_rabbit

oslo.messaging has deprecated the use of rabbit_* option settings
at the [DEFAULT] section in config file. This commit moves
the rabbit option settings to a [oslo_messaging_rabbit] section in
each of the relevant trove service when run 'devstack/plugin.sh'.

Closes-Bug: 1528391
Change-Id: Id60ea94a53ad96293846f252201416ad5b8e833d

subject: Avoid port delete race conditions
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-06-28 11:28:36.000000000', 'files': ['hyperv/neutron/hyperv_neutron_agent.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/networking-hyperv/commit/63c24f2369d1b728f684d388a275f887b577ebb4', 'message': "Avoid port delete race conditions

We are attempting to unbind a port when receiving port delete events
or RPC calls. This is prone to race conditions, as the according
methods are not synchronized.

For this reason, we get ValueErrors when attempting to update the
cached information: http://paste.openstack.org/show/523766/

While this seems harmless (besides polluting the log), it's safer
if we just put proper locks in place.

Change-Id: I854d04618eb9eabc4cee170bd21e98317ec15678
Closes-Bug: #1596916
"}]
commit_message:
Avoid port delete race conditions

We are attempting to unbind a port when receiving port delete events
or RPC calls. This is prone to race conditions, as the according
methods are not synchronized.

For this reason, we get ValueErrors when attempting to update the
cached information: http://paste.openstack.org/show/523766/

While this seems harmless (besides polluting the log), it's safer
if we just put proper locks in place.

Change-Id: I854d04618eb9eabc4cee170bd21e98317ec15678
Closes-Bug: #1596916
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/networking-hyperv refs/changes/44/334944/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: @_port_synchronized

commit_message:
release of keystonemiddleware 4.6.0

Now support installing audit support (oslo.messaging) with
"extras", other bug fixes and requirements updates.

Change-Id: I73e708793e7b71bf424cae0040cf63ebd3f1b06f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/releases refs/changes/98/336798/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: - version: 4.6.0 projects: - repo: openstack/keystonemiddleware hash: 29709a4aaf9f8851a11234380cc67285840f0216 highlights: | - Support for AuditMiddleware can be installed with `pip install keystonemiddleware[audit_notifications]` - AuditMiddleware can support services that do not use tokens (bug 1583699) - Pass X_IS_ADMIN_PROJECT header (bug 1577996) - Determine project name from oslo config or local config (bug 1583690)

commit_message:
Use assertEqual/Less/Greater/In/IsNone

Instead of using assertFalse(A * B) / assertTrue(A * B),
developers should use assertEqual/NotEqual/Less/LessEqual
/Greater/GreaterEqual/In/NotIn/IsNone/IsNotNone
The * operator: '==', '!=', '<', '<=', '>', '>='

Change-Id: I11b60a93c089f688c6b243da01d20c205c4f2df9

commit_message:
Modify allowed address pairs spec file

Add description of the detection to the active VMs who actually use the
IP/MAC addresses in allowed address pairs field of their ports.

Change-Id: I4d3740edfbc8df67062fd444664043520e9023dd
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/dragonflow refs/changes/87/334287/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: dragonflow. some scenarios) in allowed address pairs. In L2/L3 lookup table, we could VM ports which have this address in their allowed address pairs field, but that will cause extra bandwidth cost if there are only few VMs actually using the IP/MAC address in the allowed address pairs field of its port. A smarter way is sending those packets only to the ports of the VMs who actually using this IP/MAC. We can distinguish those VMs by receiving its gratuitous ARP packets of this IP/MAC from their ports, or by periodically sending ARP requests to the IP and receiving the corresponding ARP replies. Once those active VMs have been detected, local controllers should save this information in dragonflow DB and publish it. When L2/L3 APPs receive this notification, they could install flows to forwarding packets to the ports of those active VMs like they do for fixed IP/MAC. In particularly, if there is only one VM who could use the IP/MAC among VMs who have this IP/MAC in allowed address pairs field of their ports, the processes of L2/L3 APPs to install those flows could be simpler. Because this is a more common usage of allowed address pairs (for example, VRRP), we only support this situation in dragonflow as the first step. ARP table, or we could only use the detected MAC address of the active VM's port to reply ARP requests, if the active VMs mentioned above was detected.
deleted_lines: Dragonflow. some scenarios) in allowed address pairs. In L2/L3 Lookup table, we could VM ports which have this address in their allowed address pairs field. ARP table.

commit_message:
Change addCleanup create_tenant to delete_tenant, fix gate

Tempest patch with Change-Id of:
I3fe7b6b7f81a0b20888b2c70a717065e4b43674f

Changed the v2 Keystone tenant API create_tenant to keyword
arguments. This broke our API tests that used create_tenant
with a tenant_id... It looks like the addCleanup that was supposed
to delete the newly created tenant actually created a second
tenant. The existing create_tenant calls were unaffected
by the Tempest change as it is backwards compatible.

Change-Id: Ie82c16ebf8dde988d68a01fc8dfa073085af4728
Closes-Bug: #1594593

commit_message:
Allow TLD test with port in Notification Webhook Address

To allow notification webhooks to access the Top Level Domain (TLD) of test,
the validation of Webhook addresses was changed to allow urls of the form
http://test.test.  However, the validation incorrectly rejects urls with
a port, for example, http://test.test:4343

Changed the regular expression to handle the optional port. I think the
UrlValidator should have stripped it off before presenting it to
the validator, but it doesn't so the regular expression has to handle the
port

Added tempest test to verify API works with a TLD of test with and without
port

Change-Id: Ie95b4ec3c13f3f6b54aab390e234227bc81d8be9
Closes-bug: 1597070
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/monasca-api refs/changes/14/335214/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: // The UrlValidator does not take the port off of the authority so have to handle that private static final RegexValidator TEST_TLD_VALIDATOR = new RegexValidator(".+\\.test(:[0-9]+)?$");
deleted_lines: private static final RegexValidator TEST_TLD_VALIDATOR = new RegexValidator(".+\\.test$");

commit_message:
First documentation for Operational tools

This patch is a first documentation for deploying Operational tools in
TripleO.

That's a start of work and expect more content in the future, but that's
the basic structure of what we need to deploy the stack.

It includes Monitoring & Logging content for both undercloud &
overcloud.

Co-Authored-By: Swapnil Kulkarni <me@coolsvap.net>
Change-Id: I9326a46de121ba6591babe632355b78557741d4d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-docs refs/changes/71/265271/9 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Deploying Operational tools =========================== TripleO comes with an optional suite of tools designed to help operators maintain an Openstack environment. The tools perform the following functions: - Availability Monitoring - Centralised Logging This document will go through the presentation and installation of these tools. Architecture ------------ #. Undercloud: - Monitoring Relay/proxy (RabbitMQ_) - Monitoring Controller/Server (Sensu_) - API/Presentation Layer (Uchiwa_) - Log relay/transformer (Fluentd_) - Data store (Elastic_) - API/Presentation Layer (Kibana_) #. Overcloud: - Monitoring Agent (Sensu_) - Log Collection Agent (Fluentd_) .. _RabbitMQ: https://www.rabbitmq.com .. _Sensu: http://sensuapp.org .. _Uchiwa: https://uchiwa.io .. _Fluentd: http://www.fluentd.org .. _Elastic: https://www.elastic.co .. _Kibana: https://www.elastic.co/products/kibana Deploying the Undercloud ------------------------ #. Edit undercloud.conf before the deployment: - set `enable_monitoring` to `true` if you want to enable Availability Monitoring. You can also specify a password for `undercloud_sensu_password` otherwise one will be automatically generated. - set `enable_logging` to `true` if you want to enable Centralised Logging. By default, the indexes will be closed after 7 days and deleted after 10 days by using Curator_. You can change that with the 2 parameters: `elastic_close_index_days` and `elastic_delete_index_days`. .. _Curator: https://www.elastic.co/guide/en/elasticsearch/client/curator/current/index.html #. That's it, you're ready to deploy your undercloud! Deploying the Overcloud ----------------------- .. note:: The :doc:`template_deploy` doc has a more detailed explanation of the following steps. #. Copy the Operational tools configuration file to your home directory: - Availability Monitoring:: sudo cp /usr/share/openstack-tripleo-heat-templates/environments/monitoring-sensu-config.yaml ~ - Centralised Logging:: sudo cp /usr/share/openstack-tripleo-heat-templates/environments/logging-fluentd-config.yaml ~ #. Edit the permissions (user is typically ``stack``):: sudo chown $USER ~/monitoring-*-config.yaml ~/logging-*-config.yaml sudo chmod 755 ~/monitoring-*-config.yaml ~/logging-*-config.yaml #. Edit the parameters in this file to fit your requirements. #. Continue following the TripleO instructions for deploying an overcloud. Before entering the command to deploy the overcloud, add the environment file that you just configured as an argument:: openstack overcloud deploy --templates -e ~/monitoring-sensu-config.yaml -e ~/logging-fluentd-config.yaml #. Wait for the completion of the overcloud deployment process. Accessing to the dashboards --------------------------- #. Availability Monitoring: you can reach Sensu's dashboard (Uchiwa) on this URL:: http://<UNDERCLOUD_IP_ADDRESS>:3000 #. Centralised Logging: you can reach Elastic's dashboard (Kibana) on this URL:: http://<UNDERCLOUD_IP_ADDRESS>:8300/index.html#/dashboard/file/logstash.json

commit_message:
Adds Cascade option for load balancer drivers

Alternative approach to cascade deleting a load balancer through the API.
The original method was to override the normal load balancer delete and use
the cascade delete if the driver supported it.  This was backwards
incompatible.  This method just adds an action resource on the load balancer
that when called will cascade delete the load balancer.

DocImpact: Adds new API resource to delete a load balancer and its children
           in one API request.

Change-Id: I9556d78620971fd47b7834d5ff534b9c159d14fb
Co-Authored-By: German Eichberger <german.eichberger@hp.com>
Closes-bug: #1521783
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron-lbaas refs/changes/93/287593/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def delete_cascade(self, context, loadbalancer): if not self.deletes_cascade: raise NotImplementedError() super(LoadBalancerManager, self).delete(context, loadbalancer) agent = self.driver.get_loadbalancer_agent(context, loadbalancer.id) # TODO(blogan): Rethink deleting from the database here. May want to # wait until the agent actually deletes it. Doing this now to keep # what v1 had. self.driver.plugin.db.delete_loadbalancer_cascade(context, loadbalancer.id) if agent: self.driver.agent_rpc.delete_loadbalancer(context, loadbalancer, agent['host'])

commit_message:
Implement a --timeout for killing stalled scripts

This implements the feature required for bug #1595722 but the tripleo
bug is not closed until os-refresh-config is invoked with an
appropriate --timeout value.

Change-Id: Ibcbb2090aed126abec8dac49efa53ecbdb2b9b2c
DependsOn: If31f0d5d60e8585720c4c9c95cffa202f059f6f7
Partial-Bug: #1595722

commit_message:
Functional test which executes os-refresh-config

This provides functional test coverage for executing
os_refresh_config.py as a separate process.

dib-utils is added as a dependency since os-refresh-config depends on
dib-run-parts being available.

Change-Id: Ibc6232d8c1c64f660b9f86feb8b80e25ab5794d3
Related-Bug: #1595722
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/os-refresh-config refs/changes/41/333641/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines:
# # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import os import subprocess import time import fixtures import testtools script_path = os.path.join( os.path.dirname(os.path.realpath(__file__)), '../os_refresh_config.py') class TestCmd(testtools.TestCase): def setUp(self): super(TestCmd, self).setUp() self.assertTrue(os.path.exists(script_path)) self.useFixture(fixtures.NestedTempfile()) self.base_dir = self.useFixture(fixtures.TempDir()) self.lockdir = self.useFixture(fixtures.TempDir()) self.lockfile = os.path.join(self.lockdir.path, 'lock') def _run_cmd(self, args, env={}, input_str=None): subproc = subprocess.Popen(args, stdin=subprocess.PIPE, stdout=subprocess.PIPE, stderr=subprocess.PIPE, env=env) stdout, stderr = subproc.communicate(input=input_str) return subproc.returncode, stdout, stderr def _run_orc(self, *args): cmd_env = { 'OS_REFRESH_CONFIG_BASE_DIR': self.base_dir.path, 'PATH': os.environ.get('PATH') } cmd_args = [ script_path, '--lockfile', self.lockfile ] if args: cmd_args.extend(args) return self._run_cmd(cmd_args, cmd_env) def _write_script(self, phase, name, returncode=0, sleep=0): phase_dir_name = '%s.d' % phase phase_dir = self.base_dir.join(phase_dir_name) if not os.path.exists(phase_dir): os.mkdir(phase_dir) script_path = self.base_dir.join(phase_dir_name, name) script_dict = { 'name': name, 'returncode': returncode, 'sleep': sleep } with open(script_path, 'w') as f: f.write('''#!/bin/sh echo %(name)s starting sleep %(sleep)s echo %(name)s done exit %(returncode)s ''' % script_dict) os.chmod(script_path, 0o755) def test_cmd(self): returncode, stdout, stderr = self._run_orc() self.assertEqual(0, returncode) self.assertEqual('', stdout) self.assertEqual('', stderr) def test_cmd_with_scripts(self): self._write_script('pre-configure', '10-pre-first', 0, 0) self._write_script('pre-configure', '20-pre-second', 0, 1) self._write_script('configure', '10-conf-first', 0, 0) self._write_script('configure', '20-conf-second', 0, 1) self._write_script('post-configure', '10-post-first', 0, 0) self._write_script('post-configure', '20-post-second', 0, 1) now = time.time() returncode, stdout, stderr = self._run_orc() # check run time accounts for the 3 seconds of sleep self.assertTrue(time.time() - now >= 3.0) self.assertEqual('
'.join([ '10-pre-first starting', '10-pre-first done', '20-pre-second starting', '20-pre-second done', '10-conf-first starting', '10-conf-first done', '20-conf-second starting', '20-conf-second done', '10-post-first starting', '10-post-first done', '20-post-second starting', '20-post-second done', '', ]), stdout) self.assertEqual(0, returncode) def test_cmd_with_failure(self): self._write_script('pre-configure', '10-pre-first', 0) self._write_script('pre-configure', '20-pre-second', 99) self._write_script('configure', '10-conf-first', 0) returncode, stdout, stderr = self._run_orc() print(stderr) self.assertEqual('
'.join([ '10-pre-first starting', '10-pre-first done', '20-pre-second starting', '20-pre-second done', '', ]), stdout) self.assertEqual(1, returncode) def test_debug(self): returncode, stdout, stderr = self._run_orc('--log-level', 'DEBUG') self.assertEqual('', stdout) self.assertNotEqual('', stderr) self.assertEqual(0, returncode) def test_print_phases(self): returncode, stdout, stderr = self._run_orc('--print-phases') self.assertEqual( 'pre-configure	configure	post-configure	migration
', stdout ) self.assertEqual('', stderr) self.assertEqual(0, returncode) def test_print_base(self): returncode, stdout, stderr = self._run_orc('--print-base') self.assertEqual('%s
' % self.base_dir.path, stdout) self.assertEqual('', stderr) self.assertEqual(0, returncode)

commit_message:
Supports the Docker "expose" option

The Docker "expose" option allows that a port-range and protocol
be specified through the "docker run" command:
  docker run --net=my_kuryr_net --expose=1234-1238/udp -it ubuntu
This patch set implements this feature by using Neutron security
groups.

Closed-Bug: #1569142
Change-Id: Ib7e1fd4de66a7bf69d59a3bd711994b935270b66

added_lines: return response_interface, response_portdef _process_sec_group(options, port_id): exposeds = options.get(const.DOCKER_EXPOSEDPORTS_OPTION) if not exposeds: return min_port = 65536 max_port = 0 proto = '' for exposed in exposeds: port = exposed['Port'] if port < min_port: min_port = port if port > max_port: max_port = port proto = exposed['Proto'] if proto == 1: proto = 'icmp' elif proto == 6: proto = 'tcp' elif proto == 17: proto = 'udp' sec_group = { 'name': port_id, 'description': 'Docker exposed ports created by Kuryr.' } try: sg = app.neutron.create_security_group({'security_group': sec_group}) except n_exceptions.NeutronClientException as ex: app.logger.error(_LE("Error happend during creating a " "Neutron security group: {0}").format(ex)) raise sg_id = sg['security_group']['id'] sec_group_rule = { 'security_group_id': sg_id, 'direction': 'ingress', 'port_range_min': min_port, 'port_range_max': max_port, 'protocol': proto } try: app.neutron.create_security_group_rule({'security_group_rule': sec_group_rule}) except n_exceptions.NeutronClientException as ex: app.logger.error(_LE("Error happend during creating a " "Neutron security group rule: {0}").format(ex)) app.neutron.delete_security_group(sg_id) raise try: app.neutron.update_port(port_id, {'port': {'security_groups': [sg_id]}}) except n_exceptions.NeutronClientException as ex: app.logger.error(_LE("Error happend during updating a " "Neutron port: {0}").format(ex)) app.neutron.delete_security_group(sg_id) raise def _remove_sec_group(port_id): sgs = app.neutron.list_security_groups(name=port_id) sg_list = sgs.get('security_groups') if sg_list: sg_id = sg_list[0]['id'] app.neutron.delete_security_group(sg_id) response_interface, port = _create_or_update_port( _process_sec_group(json_data['Options'], port['id']) _remove_sec_group(port['id'])

commit_message:
Add DB2 full online backups for DB2

Currently Trove only supports full offline backups
for DB2. This spec details how to configure DB2
for full online backups & restore.

Implements blueprint: db2-online-backup

Change-Id: I260133431d12ea1f4aea63e49bfd408cf2454431
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/trove-specs refs/changes/64/330564/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode Sections of this template were taken directly from the Nova spec template at: https://github.com/openstack/nova-specs/blob/master/specs/juno-template.rst .. This template should be in ReSTructured text. The filename in the git repository should match the launchpad URL, for example a URL of https://blueprints.launchpad.net/trove/+spec/awesome-thing should be named awesome-thing.rst. Please do not delete any of the sections in this template. If you have nothing to say for a whole section, just write: None Note: This comment may be removed if desired, however the license notice above should remain. ==================================== DB2 Full Online Backup and Restore ==================================== Currently in Trove, we support full offline backups for DB2 which is the default backup mechanism for DB2. This enables users to take full backups of DB2 databases when no applications are connected to or using these databases. While useful for cases where this downtime is okay, it is not very useful in a production type environment were applications are expected to be online all the time. DB2 provides a way to do online backups and this spec outlines how we can implement a full online backup mechanism in Trove. Launchpad Blueprint: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/trove/+spec/db2-online-backup Problem Description =================== There are two types of backups we can perform using DB2 - offline and online. Offline backups require users and applications to be disconnected from the databases thereby requiring a certain down time. Online backups on the other hand, can be performed while users are still connected to databases. Trove currently supports full offline backups for DB2. In this spec, we explain how to enable full online backups for DB2 in Trove. Proposed Change =============== As mentioned above, the difference between offline and online backup is that in the former case all applications must disconnect from the database while in the latter, applications can still be connected to databases while backup is being taken. In order to enable online backups, archive logging needs to be enabled. This allows applications to use the database even while backups are being taken. Any updates made to the database is recorded in the logs. Logging is a mechanism where every updates to a database is recorded to transaction logs (also called active logs) as the data is being modified. There are 2 types of logging mechanism - circular and archive logging. By default, circular logging is enabled which means that after the last active log is filled, the first active log is overwritten. With circular logging as the default logging mechanism, only offline backups can be taken. Using archive logging, the logs are stored in sequence and as logs get full, they are archived. Archive logging allows users to restore databases by roll forwarding to a particular point in time or a point before failure. Hence, users can restore a database from a backup image and roll forward to a particular point using logs thus getting it to a consistent state. For an introduction to archive logging, please refer [1] and for an overview of how transactional logging works in DB2, please refer [2]. To enable full online backup for Trove, the following steps need to be taken: 1. Create a directory to store the backups and archive logs - /home/db2inst1/db2inst1/backup/ArchiveLogs 2. When a database is created, if online backups is configured for DB2(through the backup_strategy config property), then configure the following database configuration parameter: 'LOGARCHMETH1' to point to a location where the archive logs can be stored using the command: db2 update database configuration for <db> using LOGARCHMETH1 'DISK:/home/db2inst1/backup/ArchiveLogs' Setting this database configuration parameter enables archive logging and stores the archive logs in a location different from the primary/active logs.Once this change is made, a full offline backup needs to be taken before any connections can be made to the database (this is because the database goes into a 'BACKUP_PENDING' state when this configuration change is made). db2 backup database <db> to /home/db2inst1/db2inst1/backup This backup can be deleted from the backup directory after this operation. 3. The online backup strategy for DB2 will comprise of the following actions: - Check if there is enough space to store backups and archived logs - Check if archive logging is enabled for each database - Do an online backup of the database and include the archive logs along with the backup image itself: db2 backup database <db> ONLINE to /home/db2inst1/db2inst1/backup INCLUDE LOGS 4. Once the backup is complete, compress/encrypt the backup inside the volume storage. 5. The compressed/encrypted file can then be stored in Swift under the database_backups container. 6. Once the backups are stored in Swift, we can go ahead and delete the backup files and archive logs from the backup directory. Restoring a database includes restoring from an online backup image and roll forwarding the logs to the end of the backup to make sure the database is in a consistent state. 1. Create a directory where the backup files and archive logs can be stored 2. Retrieve the backup from storage to the proper location 3. Use the following commands to restore the database and ensure it is in a consistent state: - db2 RESTORE DATABASE <db> FROM <backup_dir> LOGTARGET <log_dir> The above command restores the database from the specified online backup directory and extracts the archive log files into the log_dir - db2 ROLLFORWARD DATABASE <db> TO END OF BACKLOG AND COMPLETE This command will roll forward the restored database to a consistent state by applying the archive logs. To see more details on the ROLLFORWARD command, please refer [3]. Configuration ------------- The default configuration values of the following will need to change to correspond to the respective DB2 locations. * backup_strategy * backup_namespace * restore_namespace Database -------- None Public API ---------- None Public API Security ------------------- None Python API ---------- None CLI (python-troveclient) ------------------------ None Internal API ------------ None Guest Agent ----------- The DB2 guestagent will be modified to add support for full online backup and restore functionality. In addition, new strategies will also be added to support these new features. The following guestagent files will be modified: - trove/guestagent/datastore/experimental/db2/service.py - trove/guestagent/datastore/experimental/db2/system.py and the following new strategy files will be modified to add a new class for online backups: - trove/guestagent/strategies/backup/experimental/db2_impl.py - trove/guestagent/strategies/restore/experimental/couchdb_impl.py New classes will be added for online backup strategy and the existing class needs to be renamed from DB2Backup -> DB2OfflineBackup Alternatives ------------ None Dashboard Impact (UX) ===================== None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Mariam John (johnma) Milestones ---------- Newton Work Items ---------- There will only be one work item for this feature. This includes implementing the strategies for DB2 online backup and restore and make the necessary guestagent changes. This will also include test-cases necessary to test the new functionalities. Upgrade Implications ==================== None Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= * Add new test cases to test online backup and restore functionality for DB2: - Add new unit tests to test the newly implemented functionality - Add a new DB2 helper class to the existing integration-test framework. Documentation Impact ==================== The datastore documentation should be updated to reflect the enabled features. References ========== .. [1] https://www.ibm.com/support/knowledgecenter/SSEPGG_10.5.0/com.ibm.db2.luw.admin.ha.doc/doc/c0051344.html .. [2] http://www.ibm.com/developerworks/data/library/techarticle/0301kline/0301kline.html .. [3] https://www.ibm.com/support/knowledgecenter/SSEPGG_10.5.0/com.ibm.db2.luw.admin.cmd.doc/doc/r0001978.html Appendix ======== None

commit_message:
Tri-state checkbox widget

Tri-state checkbox is the kind of checkbox which has three states
instead of two, as the regular checkbox has.

Third state is "indeterminate", which means, that that element is in
undefined state. Common example of such situation is some parent
element, which has some of child elements selected and some not - and
so it means that parent element is not selected nor unselect - which
in terminology of this changeset called "indeterminate" state.

Partially implements bp assign-category-button Depends-On:
Ie65a77eab29aa191420fbd630b1d242b59c9ff9f Change-Id:
I98116fce362af5eb4c64941f4c442dd81120e762

Change-Id: I9ea151b47d2a942184517526a9c1a9127224aa04

commit_message:
Incorrect success message of remove routers with firewall in Horizon

while updating firewall, success message is displayed like
"Router(s) was successfully removed from firewall fw." even when
no routers were actually selected to remove.

So, modified the code such that below exception is raised when there
is no change of parameters compared to the existing data in database
"Error: Failed to update firewall FW: Invalid input - No firewall
parameters were updated"

Change-Id: I8adc35f9c7b56caff87822775ad2fa1030c264c2
Closes-Bug: #1513396

commit_message:
Enhanced Network/Subnet DHCP Options

This patch adds the field extra_dhcp_opts to networks and subnets
so that it is possible to define the DHCP options applied to ports
at different levels, simplifying the configuration for scenarios where
every port in a subnet or network should have common DHCP options.
To provide this functionality additional models have been added for the
networks and subnets to store the DHCP options, and the DNSMasq driver
for the DHCP Agent has been updated to understand the new fields.

DocImpact: Document new extra_dhcp_opts fields for Subnet and Network
Change-Id: If0dbeb58f3b88f06e89e54e73dc14f13f20c6b80
Partial-Bug: #1512666
Implements: blueprint dhcp-options-per-subnet

commit_message:
Allow unknown hosts to be served by neutron dhcp

This patch adds a new field, dhcp_allow_unknown_hosts to the Subnet model
so that it is possible to enable unknown devices to be served by the
neutron dnsmasq instance.

Change-Id: Ic00f451112c69662a9e33318c3ce31f1a6776d99
Closes-Bug: #1512666

added_lines: if not getattr(subnet, 'dhcp_allow_unknown_hosts', False): if subnet.ip_version == 4: else: # Note(scollins) If the IPv6 attributes are not set, set # it as static to preserve previous behavior addr_mode = getattr(subnet, 'ipv6_address_mode', None) ra_mode = getattr(subnet, 'ipv6_ra_mode', None) if (addr_mode in [constants.DHCPV6_STATEFUL, constants.DHCPV6_STATELESS] or not addr_mode and not ra_mode): mode = 'static' elif getattr(subnet, 'dhcp_allow_unknown_hosts', False): if subnet.ip_version == 4: cmd.append('--dhcp-range=set:%s,%s,%s' % (self._TAG_PREFIX % i, cidr.network, lease)) else: cmd.append('--dhcp-range=set:%s,%s,%d,%s' % (self._TAG_PREFIX % i, cidr.network, cidr.prefixlen, lease)) possible_leases += cidr.size
deleted_lines: if subnet.ip_version == 4: mode = 'static' else: # Note(scollins) If the IPv6 attributes are not set, set # it as static to preserve previous behavior addr_mode = getattr(subnet, 'ipv6_address_mode', None) ra_mode = getattr(subnet, 'ipv6_ra_mode', None) if (addr_mode in [constants.DHCPV6_STATEFUL, constants.DHCPV6_STATELESS] or not addr_mode and not ra_mode):

subject: vm migration needs persistent state for l2pop
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-04-20 12:49:06.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/d614c8688771cd2fcd85c1ec75422a15e32c1ae8', 'message': 'vm migration needs persistent state for l2pop

VM Migrations trigger update_port_postcommit calls.
Such calls would land up on different api workers in
an environment where multiple api_workers are configured
for neutron server.  In such situations, in-memory
object references maintained inside l2pop mechdriver
instance of an api_worker, is not visible to other
mechdriver instances in other api threads.  This
results in vm migrations not handling tunnel cleanup
correctly, resulting in accumulation of tunnels on nodes.

Change-Id: Ia6e9f1615c9baead44a6ae0880563504c18774fe
Closes-Bug: #1443421
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2015-04-23 12:14:38.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/dbe7db8967ca8bab10514f2f5c4679ea913b327f', 'message': "vm migration needs persistent state for l2pop

Behaviour of l2pop on vm migration:

update_port_postcommit is invoked twice
for a migrated port.

The first time the update_port_postcommit is
triggered because of nova invocation of
update_port() that tells neutron that the port
is being made available on the new host. Nova
retains the port-status in ACTIVE state only
since nova's update_port invocation does not
alter the port-status. So during this first
update-port-postcommit invocation the l2-pop driver
uses the opportunity to save the old host information
that is available in the existing port-binding
(aka original_host in port-context).

The second time update_port_postcommit is triggered
as part of invocation of get_device_details by the
neutron agent on the new host. This invocation attempts
to bind the port which results in the migrated port-state
to transition to BUILD state. The l2pop driver uses this
opportunity to tear down the tunnels from the old host
using the saved information in the prior
update_port_postcommit.

The update_device_down from the old host would
not make it until the update_port_postcommit because,
the update_device_down call would return early due
to port not bound to this old host.

What this fix does:
VM Migrations trigger update_port_postcommit calls.
Such calls would land up on different api workers in
an environment
where multiple api_workers are configured for neutron
server.  In such situations, in-memory object references
maintained inside l2pop mechdriver instance of an
api_worker, is not visible to other mechdriver instances
in other api threads.  This results in vm migrations not
handling tunnel cleanup correctly, resulting in
accumulation of tunnels on nodes.

Change-Id: Ia6e9f1615c9baead44a6ae0880563504c18774fe
Closes-Bug: #1443421
"}, {'number': 3, 'created': '2015-04-23 12:18:15.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/2bd4950333091c27d519866208e796870868566e', 'message': "vm migration needs persistent state for l2pop

Behaviour of l2pop on vm migration:

update_port_postcommit is invoked twice
for a migrated port.

The first time the update_port_postcommit is
triggered because of nova invocation of
update_port() that tells neutron that the port
is being made available on the new host. Nova
retains the port-status in ACTIVE state only
since nova's update_port invocation does not
alter the port-status. So during this first
update-port-postcommit invocation the l2-pop driver
uses the opportunity to save the old host information
that is available in the existing port-binding
(aka original_host in port-context).

The second time update_port_postcommit is triggered
as part of invocation of get_device_details by the
neutron agent on the new host. This invocation attempts
to bind the port which results in the migrated port-state
to transition to BUILD state. The l2pop driver uses this
opportunity to tear down the tunnels from the old host
using the saved information in the prior
update_port_postcommit.

The update_device_down from the old host would
not make it until the update_port_postcommit because,
the update_device_down call would return early due
to port not bound to this old host.

What this fix does:
VM Migrations trigger update_port_postcommit calls.
Such calls would land up on different api workers in
an environment
where multiple api_workers are configured for neutron
server.  In such situations, in-memory object references
maintained inside l2pop mechdriver instance of an
api_worker, is not visible to other mechdriver instances
in other api threads.  This results in vm migrations not
handling tunnel cleanup correctly, resulting in
accumulation of tunnels on nodes. So the fix persists
l2pop migrated port state in DB, so the state is visible
to all api/rpc_workers.

Change-Id: Ia6e9f1615c9baead44a6ae0880563504c18774fe
Closes-Bug: #1443421

where multiple api_workers are configured for neutron
server.  In such situations, in-memory object references
maintained inside l2pop mechdriver instance of an
api_worker, is not visible to other mechdriver instances
in other api threads.  This results in vm migrations not
handling tunnel cleanup correctly, resulting in
accumulation of tunnels on nodes. So the fix persists
l2pop migrated port state in DB, so the state is visible
to all api/rpc_workers.

Change-Id: Ia6e9f1615c9baead44a6ae0880563504c18774fe
Closes-Bug: #1443421
'}]
commit_message:
vm migration needs persistent state for l2pop

VM Migrations trigger update_port_postcommit calls.
Such calls would land up on different api workers in
an environment
where multiple api_workers are configured for neutron
server.  In such situations, in-memory object references
maintained inside l2pop mechdriver instance of an
api_worker, is not visible to other mechdriver instances
in other api threads.  This results in vm migrations not
handling tunnel cleanup correctly, resulting in
accumulation of tunnels on nodes. So the fix persists
l2pop migrated port state in DB, so the state is visible
to all api/rpc_workers.

Change-Id: Ia6e9f1615c9baead44a6ae0880563504c18774fe
Closes-Bug: #1443421

added_lines: import sqlalchemy as sa from sqlalchemy.orm import exc as sa_excfrom neutron.db import api as db_apifrom neutron.db import model_baseclass L2popMigratedPort(model_base.BASEV2): """Represents a port that is being migrated.""" __tablename__ = 'l2popmigratedports' port_id = sa.Column(sa.String(36), sa.ForeignKey('ports.id', ondelete="CASCADE"), primary_key=True) host = sa.Column(sa.String(255), nullable=False) def push_migrated_port(self, port_id, host): session = db_api.get_session() with session.begin(subtransactions=True): try: mig_port = session.query(L2popMigratedPort).filter( L2popMigratedPort.port_id == port_id).one() except sa_exc.NoResultFound: # create here mig_port = L2popMigratedPort(port_id=port_id, host=host) session.add(mig_port) def pop_migrated_port(self, context, port_id): session = db_api.get_session() host = None port = {} with session.begin(subtransactions=True): try: port = context._plugin.get_port(context._plugin_context, port_id) mig_port = session.query(L2popMigratedPort).filter( L2popMigratedPort.port_id == port_id).one() host = mig_port.host session.delete(mig_port) except sa_exc.NoResultFound: return () return (port, host)

commit_message:
[WIP] OpenFlow based IPv6 Neighbor Discovery Responder

Couldn't sleep. Started thinking about if I could use the OpenFlow
protocol and the Nicira extensions to Open vSwitch to generate Neighbor
Advertisements for known IPv6 addresses so that we can cut down
on broadcast traffic transmitted over expensive VXLAN tunnels.

To be honest this is my first time playing around with this kind of
stuff in OpenFlow so I doubt that I've got it right.

TOOD: Unit tests, functional tests, packet dumps, and lots of poking
with tcpdump to make sure we are actually generating Neighbor
Advertisement packets that actually make sense.

Related-Bug: #1532338

Change-Id: Ie92552aa962b7cf23ecf925ceaf3794f652ca567
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/29/265629/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from ryu.lib.packet import icmpv6 @staticmethod def _nd_responder_match(ofp, ofpp, vlan, ip): return ofpp.OFPMatch(vlan_vid=vlan | ofp.OFPVID_PRESENT, eth_type=ether_types.ETH_TYPE_IPV6, nd_target=ip) def install_nd_responder(self, vlan, ip, mac): (_dp, ofp, ofpp) = self._get_dp() match = self._nd_responder_match(ofp, ofpp, vlan, ip) actions = [ ofpp.OFPActionSetField(icmpv6_type=icmpv6.ND_NEIGHBOR_ADVERT), ofpp.OFPActionSetField(nd_tll=mac), ofpp.OFPActionSetField(nd_target=ip), ofpp.OFPActionOutput(ofp.OFPP_IN_PORT, 0) ] self.install_apply_actions(table_id=constants.ARP_RESPONDER, priority=1, match=match, actions=actions) def delete_nd_responder(self, vlan, ip): match = self._nd_responder_match(ofp, ofpp, vlan, ip) self.delete_flows(table_id=constants.ARP_RESPONDER, match=match)

subject: Can not reload dnsmasq after update dhcp port
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-02-18 11:10:07.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/5e2f233e5e066087b596172940d38ebe654aeea6', 'message': 'can not reload dnsmasq after update dhcp port
when call add_network_to_dhcp_agent() method, if dhcp_port is None, it will call create_dhcp_port() method in order to create a new dhcp port,
but the method dose not put the new port into cache, so when we update the new port, it will raise a NoneType error that means the new port is not in cache.
So in this commit, use the cache by "self.cache = NetworkCache()", then put the new dhcp port into the cache by "self.cache.put_port(dhcp.DictModel(port))"
Fixes Bug1546462

Change-Id: I786c3bdf628317d70c65e05970222524282b58ed
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2016-02-18 13:56:53.000000000', 'files': ['neutron/agent/dhcp/agent.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/6900900b663c5f60cec6d68bb63bb243d127c6ea', 'message': 'Can not reload dnsmasq after update dhcp port

Currently, when call add_network_to_dhcp_agent() method,
if dhcp_port is None, create_dhcp_port() method would be called
to create a new dhcp port. But this method does nothing to put
the new port into cache. So when update the new port, a NoneType
error would be raised, finally the dnsmasq would not be reloaded.

Generally speaking, the dhcp port would be putted into cache
correctly, and dnsmasq would be reloaded successfully.

Closes-Bug: #1546462

Change-Id: I786c3bdf628317d70c65e05970222524282b58ed
'}]
commit_message:
Can not reload dnsmasq after update dhcp port

Currently, when call add_network_to_dhcp_agent() method,
if dhcp_port is None, create_dhcp_port() method would be called
to create a new dhcp port. But this method does nothing to put
the new port into cache. So when update the new port, a NoneType
error would be raised, finally the dnsmasq would not be reloaded.

Generally speaking, the dhcp port would be putted into cache
correctly, and dnsmasq would be reloaded successfully.

Closes-Bug: #1546462

Change-Id: I786c3bdf628317d70c65e05970222524282b58ed
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/65/281765/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: self.cache = NetworkCache() self.cache.put_port(dhcp.DictModel(port))

commit_message:
Fix subnet update to no-gateway without l3 check

port of network:router_interface exists even if the subnet updated to
no-gateway

This patch add ckeck and router interface delete process:
when update subnet --no-gateway:
 * check and router interface delete
 * delete or update gateway port
 * nofity subnet update

Change-Id: Ifffe40f4d436ed5e88f6b2036a248cdef7598a46
Closes-Bug: #1554837
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/45/293245/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: router_id = None gw_port = None ports = self.get_ports(context) for port in ports: for ip in port['fixed_ips']: if ip['subnet_id'] == s['id']: if "router_interface" in port['device_owner']: router_id = port['device_id'] gw_port = port['id'] if not gateway_ip and router_id: l3plugin = manager.NeutronManager.get_service_plugins().get( service_constants.L3_ROUTER_NAT) l3plugin.remove_router_interface(context, router_id, {'subnet_id': s['id']}) elif router_id: self.update_port(context, gw_port['id'], gw_port) l3_rpc_notifier = l3_rpc_agent_api.L3AgentNotifyAPI() l3_rpc_notifier.routers_updated(context, [router_id])
deleted_lines: update_ports_needed = False update_ports_needed = True # Provide pre-update notification not to break plugins that don't # support gateway ip change if update_ports_needed: # Find ports that have not yet been updated # with an IP address by Prefix Delegation, and update them ports = self.get_ports(context) routers = [] for port in ports: fixed_ips = [] new_port = {'port': port} for ip in port['fixed_ips']: if ip['subnet_id'] == s['id']: fixed_ip = {'subnet_id': s['id']} if "router_interface" in port['device_owner']: routers.append(port['device_id']) fixed_ip['ip_address'] = s['gateway_ip'] fixed_ips.append(fixed_ip) if fixed_ips: new_port['port']['fixed_ips'] = fixed_ips self.update_port(context, port['id'], new_port) # Send router_update to l3_agent if routers: l3_rpc_notifier = l3_rpc_agent_api.L3AgentNotifyAPI() l3_rpc_notifier.routers_updated(context, routers)

commit_message:
Consolidate the OVS DF and CSUM options into constants

The 'dont_fragment' and 'tunnel_csum' options are present in both
the agent configuration, as well as being optional keyword args to a
method in ovs_lib. Since they are the same options with the same values,
let's not repeat ourselves.

Change-Id: I566e1159027d262c56f7cea6423f1dcb3ca6bd53

commit_message:
[WIP] Deprecate the tunnel_csum option for OVS in favor of autodetection

Mailing list thread:

http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2016-February/086083.html

We should try and do some self discovery to see if we have a new enough
kernel and new enough Open vSwitch that we can enable this option.

The performance improvements are very compelling.

http://openvswitch.org/pipermail/dev/2015-August/059335.html

"We found that enabling UDP checksums for vxlan triggers GRO on the
receiver, and boosts the vxlan performance to 8+ Gbps."

Change-Id: I9f790962502919a7fb604c881b963d9d24135030

commit_message:
Configure IPv6 on HA router only if IPv6 is enabled

L3 agent should check if IPv6 is disabled on the system
and create HA router namespace with IPv6 disabled.

This is required especially in case of L3 HA because,
Neigbhor discovery and Multicast listener report results
in physical switch re-learn the MAC address of the
external port, and place it on a port that's looking at
a standby and not at the master.
This causes 100% packet loss for any incoming traffic
that should be going through the master instance of the
router.

Also in environment where IPv6 is disabled, this behavior
of L3 agent results in IPv6 packets in the network.

This patch introduces a check in L3 agent to create HA
router namespace with IPv6 disabled if IPv6 addressing
is disabled on the system.

Closes-Bug: #1551065

Change-Id: I2fe20cac59237dc0980f51608f1ffbcb68f51d50
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/19/283919/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

'}, {'number': 10, 'created': '2015-11-22 07:22:28.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/af71c5f18c92f810f650f37a23278b9248f77945', 'message': "remove FIP ip from centralized router device

Current code will try to adding floating IP address onto
external gateway device in centralized router namespace.
It's a convenient way to do proxy arp for centralized router.
But for DVR router, specially the DVR local router, it
inherits the same why to configure floating IP address, so
it will cause issue in [1].

The solution is fixing previous SNAT iptable rules and removing
floating IP addresses from router_2_fip device in DVR local router
namespace. The needed-by patch will work on that.

But that will make DVR router has different behaviors on floating
IP processing. Per [2], we can unify floating IP processing for DVR
router and centralized router, by removing floating IP address from
certain devices, and adding route for floating IP address to do proxy
arp.

Additionally, this patch also fix fixed_ip ip error
for floating IP in functional test.

[1] a VM ping another VM on the same host with the later one's
floating IP address, but get replied by the later one's fixed
IP address. https://bugs.launchpad.net/neutron/+bug/1462154
[2] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/240677/10//COMMIT_MSG

Co-Authored-By: stephen-ma <stephen.ma@hpe.com>
Partial-Bug: #1462154
Change-Id: Ie47126e010876400f5a9a6e661e4d3709bfc10dd
"}, {'number': 11, 'created': '2015-11-24 08:46:48.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/3187a1d1de659fe51715ff5105fe69398d9d845d', 'message': "remove floatingip address from router device

Current code will try to add floating IP address to
external gateway device in centralized router namespace.
It's a convenient way to do proxy arp for centralized router.
But for DVR router, specially the DVR local router, it
inherits the same way to configure floating IP address, so
it will cause issue in [1].

The solution is fixing previous SNAT iptable rules and removing
floating IP addresses from router_2_fip device in DVR local router
namespace. The needed-by patch will work on that.

But that will make DVR router has different behaviors on floating
IP processing. Per [2], we can unify floating IP processing for DVR
router and centralized router, by removing floating IP address from
certain devices, and adding route for floating IP address to do proxy
arp.

Additionally, this patch also fix fixed_ip IP error for floating IP,
in [3]l3_test_common and functional tests. The floating IP which we
are going to use in tests, its fixed_ip IP address doesn't belong to
[4]router interface subnets scope.

[1] a VM ping another VM on the same host with the later one's
floating IP address, but get replied by the later one's fixed
IP address. https://bugs.launchpad.net/neutron/+bug/1462154
[2] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/240677/10//COMMIT_MSG
[3] https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/master/neutron/tests/common/l3_test_common.py#L112
[4] https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/master/neutron/tests/common/l3_test_common.py#L145

Co-Authored-By: stephen-ma <stephen.ma@hpe.com>
Partial-Bug: #1462154
Change-Id: Ie47126e010876400f5a9a6e661e4d3709bfc10dd
"}, {'number': 12, 'created': '2015-12-09 10:37:58.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/263a13ae4fc8f6ed729664a340b41ea6f8ce6370', 'message': "Remove floatingip address from router device

Current code will try to add floating IP address to external gateway
device in centralized router namespace. It's a convenient way to do
proxy arp for centralized router. But for DVR router, specially the
DVR local router, it inherits the same way to configure floating IP
address, so it will cause issue in [1]. Traffic sent to a floating
IP which happens to map to a fixed ip on the same network should go
through the routers default SNAT. In DVR, this means routing the traffic
through the centralized SNAT part of the router. The problem is that
since the IP address is configured on the router's device, it thinks
it owns the address and will not route it through.

The solution is fixing previous SNAT iptable rules and removing
floating IP addresses from router_2_fip device in DVR local router
namespace. The needed-by patch will work on that.

But that will mean the DVR router would handle floating IPs inconsistently
with non-DVR routers. Since the only reason to add the address to the
router's interface is for proxy arp, we can instead configure arp proxy
in all cases to be consistent.

Additionally, this patch also fix fixed_ip IP error for floating IP,
in method prepare_router_data and functional tests.
Method prepare_router_data can give us a router data object with a
default floating IP with '10.0.0.1'[2] as fixed_ip_address, but all the
router's IPv4 cidrs are in style '35.4.x.0/24'[3]. That doesn't make
any sense.

[1] a VM ping another VM on the same host with the later one's
floating IP address, but get replied by the later one's fixed
IP address. https://bugs.launchpad.net/neutron/+bug/1462154
[2] https://goo.gl/9Z2fUx
[3] https://goo.gl/ZbzdZZ

Co-Authored-By: stephen-ma <stephen.ma@hpe.com>
Partial-Bug: #1462154
Change-Id: Ie47126e010876400f5a9a6e661e4d3709bfc10dd
"}, {'number': 13, 'created': '2015-12-14 08:58:27.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/30cfbb0f1c7812ae380bed99f5f7bad91d6ef7b5', 'message': "Remove floatingip addresses from router device

Current code will try to add floating IP address to external gateway
device in centralized router namespace. It's a convenient way to do
proxy arp for centralized router. But for DVR router, specially the
DVR local router, it inherits the same way to configure floating IP
address, so it will cause issue in [1]. Traffic sent to a floating
IP which happens to map to a fixed ip on the same network should go
through the routers default SNAT. In DVR, this means routing the traffic
through the centralized SNAT part of the router. The problem is that
since the IP address is configured on the router's device, it thinks
it owns the address and will not route it through.

The solution is fixing previous SNAT iptable rules and removing
floating IP addresses from router_2_fip device in DVR local router
namespace. The needed-by patch[2] will work on that.

But that will mean the DVR router would handle floating IPs inconsistently
with non-DVR routers. Since the only reason to add the address to the
router's interface is for proxy arp, we can instead configure arp proxy
in all cases to be consistent.

Additionally, this patch also fixes fixed_ip IP error for floating IP,
in method prepare_router_data and functional tests.
Method prepare_router_data can give us a router data object with a
default floating IP with '10.0.0.1'[3] as fixed_ip_address, but all the
router's IPv4 cidrs are in style '35.4.x.0/24'[4]. That doesn't make
any sense, and will stop new method named get_fip_route_nexthop in this
patch to work.

[1] a VM ping another VM on the same host with the later one's
floating IP address, but get replied by the later one's fixed
IP address. https://bugs.launchpad.net/neutron/+bug/1462154
[2] remove floating IP address from DVR router device
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/246894/
[3] https://goo.gl/9Z2fUx
[4] https://goo.gl/ZbzdZZ

Co-Authored-By: stephen-ma <stephen.ma@hpe.com>
Partial-Bug: #1462154
Change-Id: Ie47126e010876400f5a9a6e661e4d3709bfc10dd

"}, {'number': 16, 'created': '2015-12-17 08:22:13.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/25175cc17f4959da0266fc46a4caef81e50cff39', 'message': "Remove floatingip addresses from router device

Current code will try to add floating IP address to external gateway
device in centralized router namespace. It's a convenient way to do
proxy arp for centralized router. But for DVR router, specially the
DVR local router, it inherits the same way to configure floating IP
address, so it will cause issue in [1]. Traffic sent to a floating
IP which happens to map to a fixed ip on the same network should go
through the routers default SNAT. In DVR, this means routing the traffic
through the centralized SNAT part of the router. The problem is that
since the IP address is configured on the router's device, it thinks
it owns the address and will not route it through.

The solution is fixing previous SNAT iptable rules and removing
floating IP addresses from router_2_fip device in DVR local router
namespace. The needed-by patch[2] will work on that.

But that will mean the DVR router would handle floating IPs inconsistently
with non-DVR routers. Since the only reason to add the address to the
router's interface is for proxy arp, we can instead configure arp proxy
in all cases to be consistent.

Additionally, this patch also fixes fixed_ip IP error for floating IP,
in method prepare_router_data and functional tests.
Method prepare_router_data can give us a router data object with a
default floating IP with '10.0.0.1'[3] as fixed_ip_address, but all the
router's IPv4 cidrs are in style '35.4.x.0/24'[4]. That doesn't make
any sense, and will stop new method named get_fip_route_nexthop in this
patch to work.

[1] a VM ping another VM on the same host with the later one's
floating IP address, but get replied by the later one's fixed
IP address. https://bugs.launchpad.net/neutron/+bug/1462154
[2] remove floating IP address from DVR router device
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/246894/
[3] https://goo.gl/9Z2fUx
[4] https://goo.gl/ZbzdZZ

UpgradeImpact

Co-Authored-By: stephen-ma <stephen.ma@hpe.com>
Partial-Bug: #1462154
Change-Id: Ie47126e010876400f5a9a6e661e4d3709bfc10dd

IP address. https://bugs.launchpad.net/neutron/+bug/1462154
[2] remove floating IP address from DVR router device

commit_message:
Remove floatingip addresses from router device

Current code will try to add floating IP address to external gateway
device in centralized router namespace. It's a convenient way to do
proxy arp for centralized router. But for DVR router, specially the
DVR local router, it inherits the same way to configure floating IP
address, so it will cause issue in [1]. Traffic sent to a floating
IP which happens to map to a fixed ip on the same network should go
through the routers default SNAT. In DVR, this means routing the traffic
through the centralized SNAT part of the router. The problem is that
since the IP address is configured on the router's device, it thinks
it owns the address and will not route it through.

The solution is fixing previous SNAT iptable rules and removing
floating IP addresses from router_2_fip device in DVR local router
namespace. The needed-by patch[2] will work on that.

But that will mean the DVR router would handle floating IPs inconsistently
with non-DVR routers. Since the only reason to add the address to the
router's interface is for proxy arp, we can instead configure arp proxy
in all cases to be consistent.

[1] a VM ping another VM on the same host with the later one's
floating IP address, but get replied by the later one's fixed
IP address. https://bugs.launchpad.net/neutron/+bug/1462154
[2] remove floating IP address from DVR router device
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/246894/

UpgradeImpact

Co-Authored-By: stephen-ma <stephen.ma@hpe.com>
Partial-Bug: #1462154
Change-Id: Ie47126e010876400f5a9a6e661e4d3709bfc10dd
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/55/246855/10 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

its processing seems unnecessary, for:
* when agent is in 'dvr' mode, it should onyl return floatingips
  hosted by given agent/host.
* when agent is not in 'dvr' mode, it should return:
  * all floatingips when router is not DVR router;

this patch try to optimize _get_dvr_sync_data.

commit_message:
Optimize _get_dvr_sync_data for floatingip

Previous processing in _get_dvr_sync_data will do host filter
for floatingip(in python logic, not by DB query), and for that
its processing seems unnecessary, for:
* when agent is in 'dvr' mode, it should only return floatingips
  hosted by given agent/host.
* when agent is not in 'dvr' mode, it should return:
  * all floatingips when router is not DVR router;
  * only floatingips hosted by given agent/host when router is
    DVR router.

When above logic can be done in DB query, we can save those
unnecessary processing for floatingip. And this is the point
this patch try to optimize _get_dvr_sync_data.

Closes-Bug: #1533313
Change-Id: Ifec8c58436228ba54635025b59a49b5916bdf444
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/52/266152/9 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from neutron.plugins.ml2 import models as ml2_models def _get_sync_floating_ips(self, context, router_ids, host=None): # Filter out on fixed_ip binding host if host is given if host: query = query.join(ml2_models.PortBinding, ml2_models.PortBinding.port_id == models_v2.Port.id) query = query.filter(ml2_models.PortBinding.host == host) device_owners=None, host=None): floating_ips = self._get_sync_floating_ips( context, router_ids, host)
deleted_lines: def _get_sync_floating_ips(self, context, router_ids): device_owners=None): floating_ips = self._get_sync_floating_ips(context, router_ids)

subject: Fix TestDvrRouter for dual_stack router dict
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-01-19 15:36:38.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/0fff1af5485900e2608f1d3b2cddbc86bfd9bf62', 'message': 'Fix _add_snat_port_info_to_router for functional test

In _add_snat_port_info_to_router, it has code like:
  def _add_snat_port_info_to_router(self, router, internal_ports):
      # Add snat port information to the router
      snat_port_list = router.get(l3_constants.SNAT_ROUTER_INTF_KEY, [])
      if not snat_port_list and internal_ports:
          ...
          router[l3_constants.SNAT_ROUTER_INTF_KEY] = [
              {...} # <-this is single snat port dict
          ]
it's OK for previous tests, for most of them use "num_internal_ports=1"
as default to get a router dict to test, and for others whom don't have
verifications around snat interface will not get affect.

But since I37e0d0d723fcc727faa09028045b776957c75a82 updated
"num_internal_ports=2" to get a router with internal interfaces to test.
Any patches want to do verifications with snat interfaces will fail.
People can check "DVR: SNAT port not found in the list" in
http://goo.gl/zk84pk to find that.

Change-Id: I07b93c96942bd1577abe1a882c7931b58c542cc8
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2016-03-02 05:45:36.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/66183cce91a6b7d16587cea2b2014bf2cd841f74', 'message': 'Fix TestDvrRouter for dual_stack router dict

In TestDvrRouter, method _add_snat_port_info_to_router and
_add_fip_agent_gw_port_info_to_router will add fip agent gateway port
info and snat port info to router dict, per info in external gateway
port info and internal ports info in router dict.

When a router dict is created with dual_stack set to True, its external
gateway port will two subnets and two fixed_ips, and each of its
internal ports will also have two subnets and two fixed_ips, one for
IPv4 and another for IPv6.

But currently, these two methods will only process the first subnet and
fixed_ip for router dict, which make dual_stack fail to work.

This patch will fix the problem mentioned above, and make sure all
subnets and fixed_ips in router dict get been processed.

Closes-Bug: #1552070
Change-Id: I07b93c96942bd1577abe1a882c7931b58c542cc8

commit_message:
Fix TestDvrRouter for dual_stack router dict

In TestDvrRouter, method _add_snat_port_info_to_router and
_add_fip_agent_gw_port_info_to_router will add fip agent gateway port
info and snat port info to router dict, per info in external gateway
port info and internal ports info in router dict.

When a router dict is created with dual_stack set to True, its external
gateway port will two subnets and two fixed_ips, and each of its
internal ports will also have two subnets and two fixed_ips, one for
IPv4 and another for IPv6.

But currently, these two methods will only process the first subnet and
fixed_ip for router dict, which make dual_stack fail to work.

This patch will fix the problem mentioned above, and make sure all
subnets and fixed_ips in router dict get been processed.

Closes-Bug: #1552070
Change-Id: I07b93c96942bd1577abe1a882c7931b58c542cc8

commit_message:
L3_NAT_dbonly_mixin: Add disassociate_floatingips do_notify argument

As ML2 specifies the argument unconditionally.
This allows a db-only L3 service plugin to be used with ML2.

Partial-Bug: #1525881
Change-Id: Ib0e51b7e6747621c789d457c19564af39eeedfc7

commit_message:
DVR: Remove fip netns default gw after subnet update

Currently, after external subnet updates with --no-gateway parameter,
DVR fip netns related that external network will still keep the
stale old default gateway. It should delete the stale default gateway,
since external subnet is set no gateway now.

This patch will fix that, make stale default gateway be deleted in
fip netns after external subnet updated to no gateway.

Closes-Bug: #1551596
Change-Id: Idd4dd055e96e8b312000325ce1057909768746ab
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/62/270662/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def test_dvr_router_with_fips_update_external_net_gateway(self): self.agent.conf.agent_mode = 'dvr' router_info = self.generate_dvr_router_info() router = self.manage_router(self.agent, router_info) fip_ns_name = router.fip_ns.get_name() prev_fip_routes = ip_lib.IPRoute(fip_ns_name).route.list_routes( l3_constants.IP_VERSION_4) dev = router.fip_ns.get_ext_device_name( router.fip_ns.agent_gateway_port['id']) via = router.fip_ns.agent_gateway_port['subnets'][0]['gateway_ip'] default_gw_route = { 'cidr': '0.0.0.0/0', 'dev': dev, 'via': via } self.assertIn(default_gw_route, prev_fip_routes) new_via = '19.4.4.254' fip_agent_ports = router.router[l3_constants.FLOATINGIP_AGENT_INTF_KEY] fip_agent_ports[0]['subnets'][0]['gateway_ip'] = new_via router.process_external(self.agent) new_fip_routes = ip_lib.IPRoute(fip_ns_name).route.list_routes( l3_constants.IP_VERSION_4) default_gw_route = { 'cidr': '0.0.0.0/0', 'dev': dev, 'via': new_via } self.assertIn(default_gw_route, new_fip_routes) def test_dvr_router_with_fips_update_external_net_gateway_to_no_gw(self): self.agent.conf.agent_mode = 'dvr' router_info = self.generate_dvr_router_info() router = self.manage_router(self.agent, router_info) fip_ns_name = router.fip_ns.get_name() prev_fip_routes = ip_lib.IPRoute(fip_ns_name).route.list_routes( l3_constants.IP_VERSION_4) dev = router.fip_ns.get_ext_device_name( router.fip_ns.agent_gateway_port['id']) via = router.fip_ns.agent_gateway_port['subnets'][0]['gateway_ip'] default_gw_route = { 'cidr': '0.0.0.0/0', 'dev': dev, 'via': via } self.assertIn(default_gw_route, prev_fip_routes) fip_agent_ports = router.router[l3_constants.FLOATINGIP_AGENT_INTF_KEY] fip_agent_ports[0]['subnets'][0]['gateway_ip'] = None router.process_external(self.agent) new_fip_routes = ip_lib.IPRoute(fip_ns_name).route.list_routes( l3_constants.IP_VERSION_4) self.assertNotIn(default_gw_route, new_fip_routes) self.assertEqual(len(prev_fip_routes) -1, len(new_fip_routes))

commit_message:
Adds support to provide udpcsum option for Linux Bridge

The new option for the linux bridge agent will enable to
set/unset the udpcsum option for the vxlan tunnels.
This enables GRO on the receiver with some network card.
The default is maintained as False.

This feature requires kernel 3.16+[1] and iproute2 3.18.0+[2]

[1] http://kernelnewbies.org/Linux_3.16
[2] http://lists.openwall.net/netdev/2014/11/07/103

DocImpact: Add udpcsum option to enable GRO on the receiver
Change-Id: Ice9584ef9ad2a8df4dac303b5a6b63e398526463
Closes-bug:  #1515069
Related-Bug: #1492111
Signed-off-by: Takashi Okamoto <okamoto_takashi_p3@lab.ntt.co.jp>

commit_message:
Make keepalived add_vip idempotent

L3 agent operations are designed to be idempotent to be resiliant
in the face of missed notifications, out of order notifications
processing and agent restarts. One exception is keepalived's
add_vip that was made to explicitly barf when the agent tries
to add a vip that was already inserted to keepalive'd internal
cache. This was done in patch 142630 by my request to root
out bugs. Well, we found such a bug and in retrospect may not
have been the smartest idea.

Change-Id: Iead975787e2847828286d7b644dcbe33cf57ace9
Related-Bug: #1523999
(cherry picked from commit eb84048bbc27d6743016da9beeda071ccb92cd9c)

commit_message:
WIP: Adds consumers executor_type

When creating consumers, an executor_type can be specified
to oslo_messaging, which specifies which kind of executor
to use when handling messages.

Accepted values are: eventlet, threading, blocking.

Neutron will create eventlet consumers by default.

Change-Id: Ib7d2fbea3265e6665e5f0267658aa2d88061c864

subject: POC: Use DLM for locking L3's scheduler
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-03-09 16:59:17.000000000', 'files': ['neutron/coordinator.py', 'neutron/services/l3_router/l3_router_plugin.py', 'neutron/scheduler/l3_agent_scheduler.py', 'neutron/plugins/ml2/plugin.py', 'neutron/common/exceptions.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/652796ae0223846a25593fd4e6046e6a19d51b29', 'message': 'POC: Use DLM for locking L3's scheduler

The existing code that exists for the l3 scheduler is extremely raceful
since multiple workers (initiated from both RPC and API) can call this
code. One option to deal with these races is sending numerous patches
that check these races and if found - fix them. The other option is
using a DLM (Distributed Locking Mechanism).

Thankfully, OpenStack already has a DLM library called tooz, and this
patch introduces it to Neutron.

This patch exists mainly to show that "it can be done" and that it's
quite easy. There are multiple details to look into here, including:
1. Which backend do we want? (I chose redis because ceilometer uses it
   but a few more are available, including etcd, consul, ZooKeeper...)
   Also, need to add devstack support for whichever one we use
2. Do we want to use a ring-based synchronization method? A centralized
   managing entity? A consensus-based algorithm? If so, how many to
   establish a consensus?
3. How often do we want to update that we're up? (I used a hard-coded
   10 but we probably want it to be configurable)
4. ...?

Closes-Bug: #1552680
Change-Id: Id019e55ddb9d030220be961a474aea30a583d334
'}]
commit_message:
POC: Use DLM for locking L3's scheduler

The existing code that exists for the l3 scheduler is extremely raceful
since multiple workers (initiated from both RPC and API) can call this
code. One option to deal with these races is sending numerous patches
that check these races and if found - fix them. The other option is
using a DLM (Distributed Locking Mechanism).

Thankfully, OpenStack already has a DLM library called tooz, and this
patch introduces it to Neutron.

This patch exists mainly to show that "it can be done" and that it's
quite easy. There are multiple details to look into here, including:
1. Which backend do we want? (I chose redis because ceilometer uses it
   but a few more are available, including etcd, consul, ZooKeeper...)
   Also, need to add devstack support for whichever one we use
2. Do we want to use a ring-based synchronization method? A centralized
   managing entity? A consensus-based algorithm? If so, how many to
   establish a consensus?
3. How often do we want to update that we're up? (I used a hard-coded
   10 but we probably want it to be configurable)
4. ...?

Closes-Bug: #1552680
Change-Id: Id019e55ddb9d030220be961a474aea30a583d334

commit_message:
WIP: add extend quota left api in quota show

We can send rest request like:
xxx/quotas/[tenant_id]?left=True[&query_type=[network,subnet,router,rbac_policies]]
to query the current quota left of specified tenant. This patch add the
logic code and tests.

Change-Id: I27def3e35d80f9aefd00cf1b5faf2a5317250068
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/70/293770/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from neutron import manager def get_tennant_left_quotas(context, resources, tenant_id, query_type='all'): plugin = manager.NeutronManager.get_plugin() if query_type == 'all': tenant_left_quota = DbQuotaDriver.get_tenant_quotas( context, resources, tenant_id) current_usages = dict( (resource, resources[resource].count( context, plugin, tenant_id, resync_usage=False)) for resource in resources.keys()) resource_list = resources.keys() else: tenant_left_quota = dict((key, resources.get(key).default) for key in query_type) q_qry1 = common_db.model_query( context, quota_models.Quota).filter_by( tenant_id=tenant_id).filter( quota_models.Quota.resource.in_(query_type)) for i in q_qry1: tenant_left_quota[i['resource']] = i['limit'] current_usages = dict( (resource, resources[resource].count( context, plugin, tenant_id, resync_usage=False)) for resource in query_type) resource_list = query_type for resource in resource_list: if tenant_left_quota[resource] == -1: continue else: tenant_left_quota[resource] -= current_usages[resource] return tenant_left_quota @staticmethod

subject: Avoid multiple gw ports on the same router WIP
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-01-29 11:31:57.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/63124b25b94893f7420c7cbe15314ae37dc4aaf4', 'message': "Avoid multiple gw ports on the same router

A port can be manually created by assigning the device owner as
--device_owner='network:router_gateway' to a router that already
has a default gateway for the same network. This causes the
router to have two default gateways for the same network.

This patch adds a new check to fix this and shows the information
to the user with the router device and network UUIDs.

Change-Id: I22a5ee1b17f37130bed35d6d4a25dfa1186c11da
Closes-Bug: #1430345
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2016-01-29 11:39:22.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/c9b16a3bf75816f636ac646b958b4ad679a5f2c0', 'message': "Avoid multiple gw ports on the same router

A port can be manually created by assigning the device owner as
--device_owner='network:router_gateway' to a router that already
has a default gateway for the same network. This causes the
router to have two default gateways for the same network.

This patch adds a new check to fix this and shows the information
to the user with the router device and network UUIDs.
This borrows the original idea and test code from @akamyshnikova's
patch for the same issue.

Change-Id: I22a5ee1b17f37130bed35d6d4a25dfa1186c11da
Closes-Bug: #1430345

WIP: just a base for discussion

A port can be manually created by assigning the device owner as
--device_owner='network:router_gateway' to a router that already has a
default gateway for the same network. This causes the router to have two
default gateways for the same network.

This patch disallows to create directly gateway ports or to transform
ports into gateway ports. Router gateway has to be set by updating
'external_gateway_info'. This is done through specific validators for
internal/external port create/update.

  should be updated in the API docs and CLI command manuals.

Change-Id: I22a5ee1b17f37130bed35d6d4a25dfa1186c11da
Closes-Bug: #1430345
"}]
commit_message:
Avoid multiple gw ports on the same router WIP

WIP: just a base for discussion

A port can be manually created by assigning the device owner as
--device_owner='network:router_gateway' to a router that already has a
default gateway for the same network. This causes the router to have two
default gateways for the same network.

This patch disallows to create directly gateway ports or to transform
ports into gateway ports. Router gateway has to be set by updating
'external_gateway_info'. This is done through specific validators for
internal/external port create/update.

UpgradeImpact:
   Port creation and update does not work with the
  --device_owner='network:router_gateway' option.
DocImpact:
  This new restriction to the port create/update operation
  should be updated in the API docs and CLI command manuals.
Co-Authored-By: Cedric Brandily <zzelle@gmail.com>
Change-Id: I22a5ee1b17f37130bed35d6d4a25dfa1186c11da
Closes-Bug: #1430345

added_lines: from debtcollector import removals from neutron_lib.db import _api as lib_db_apiremovals.removed_module(__name__, replacement=lib_db_api.__name__, version='Newton', removal_version='Ocata') MAX_RETRIES = lib_db_api.MAX_RETRIES is_deadlock = lib_db_api.is_deadlock retry_db_errors = lib_db_api.retry_db_errors exc_to_retry = lib_db_api.exc_to_retry get_engine = lib_db_api.get_engine dispose = lib_db_api.dispose get_session = lib_db_api.get_session
deleted_lines: from oslo_config import cfg from oslo_db import api as oslo_db_api from oslo_db import exception as db_exc from oslo_db.sqlalchemy import session from oslo_utils import excutils_FACADE = None MAX_RETRIES = 10 is_deadlock = lambda e: isinstance(e, db_exc.DBDeadlock) retry_db_errors = oslo_db_api.wrap_db_retry( max_retries=MAX_RETRIES, retry_on_request=True, exception_checker=is_deadlock ) @contextlib.contextmanager def exc_to_retry(exceptions): try: yield except Exception as e: with excutils.save_and_reraise_exception() as ctx: if isinstance(e, exceptions): ctx.reraise = False raise db_exc.RetryRequest(e) def _create_facade_lazily(): global _FACADE if _FACADE is None: _FACADE = session.EngineFacade.from_config(cfg.CONF, sqlite_fk=True) return _FACADE def get_engine(): """Helper method to grab engine.""" facade = _create_facade_lazily() return facade.get_engine() def dispose(): # Don't need to do anything if an enginefacade hasn't been created if _FACADE is not None: get_engine().pool.dispose() def get_session(autocommit=True, expire_on_commit=False, use_slave=False): """Helper method to grab session.""" facade = _create_facade_lazily() return facade.get_session(autocommit=autocommit, expire_on_commit=expire_on_commit, use_slave=use_slave)

commit_message:
Adds cascading delete flag for LBaaSv2

This patch adds the "--cascade" flag for the
"lbaas-loadbalancer-delete" command
to support the cascading delete of a load balancer

Partial-Bug: #1521783
Depends-On: I9556d78620971fd47b7834d5ff534b9c159d14fb
Change-Id: I30f036f92d1f861f2d982ec95cc71b7237a34335
