commit_message:
Neutron IETF Service Function Chaining API

The ability to dynamically instantiate Service Function Chains (SFCs) is
sought by many. Doing so with OpenStack via Neutron brings additional
value since basic networking is already handled and a framework is in
place for translating network abstractions to back-ends such as
virtual switches and SDN controllers. With that in mind, only additional
logic for traffic classification and steering, plus an API capable of
reflecting these capabilities, needs to be added to make Neutron the single
API necessary to instantiate and manage Service Function Chains together
with the pure networking abstraction.

Change-Id: I7c6661c5447f92437f22002abad04f6105eeec79
Partial-Bug: #1572656
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron-specs refs/changes/53/308453/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================================== Neutron IETF Service Function Chaining API ========================================== The ability to dynamically instantiate Service Function Chains (SFCs) is sought by many. Doing so with OpenStack via Neutron brings additional value since basic networking is already handled and a framework is in place for translating network abstractions to back-ends such as virtual switches and SDN controllers. With that in mind, only additional logic for traffic classification and steering, plus an API capable of reflecting these capabilities, needs to be added to make Neutron the single API necessary to instantiate and manage Service Function Chains together with the pure networking abstraction. Problem Description =================== Today, with OpenStack, it is possible to steer traffic between an ordered set of virtual machines based on specific traffic classification criteria, through the Neutron API extension provided by openstack/networking-sfc [1]. The networking-sfc project has made significant progress in this space, and there is a lot of value in what has been completed. However, looking at the standardization efforts around Service Function Chaining (SFC), led by the IETF SFC Working Group (WG) [2], it would be beneficial to develop an SFC API and related classification functionality in OpenStack that aligns with the standards work. The use cases for Service Function Chaining are also being debated at the IETF SFC WG, but the value of them when applied to Neutron can be summarized as the following: * When OpenStack is already deployed as a Virtualisation Infrastructure Manager (VIM) (from the ETSI architectural framework [3]), having the ability to manage SFC while reusing all the functionality provided by OpenStack is an advantage. By combining the network abstractions and southbound support provided by Neutron, plus the ability to instantiate and manage virtual machines and other resources common to an OpenStack deployment on multiple nodes, we can have a single set of consistent, non-conflicting API endpoints, and properly abstract the underlying layers (e.g. there should be no need to directly instantiate SFCs through a custom SDN controller, if Neutron is already capable of interacting with SDN controllers to implement network abstractions). Furthermore, the following use cases, concepts and core SFC architecture components [4] should be supported on an SFC-capable networking API to enable their use and propagation to underlying virtual switches or custom SDN controllers, abstracting and/or translating where relevant: * SFC Encapsulation; * Reclassification and Branching; * Choice of network transport protocols for the SFC encapsulation; * SFC Proxying; * Criteria for Elasticity and Load Balancing; * SFC Symmetry; Finally, since there isn't, yet, widespread use of SFC Encapsulation, partly influenced by the lack of an API supporting such a concept in a cloud management system like OpenStack, there is still the need to support "legacy" service chains in the short-term. In other words, service chains that don't make use of SFC encapsulation, reclassification, metadata, etc., instead relying on basic traffic steering based on specific classifications. Proposed Change =============== To solve this problem, a new SFC API for Neutron is proposed, compliant as much as possible with the standardization efforts that have been and are being made. The end result is the ability to specify the plumbing between Neutron ports based on traffic classification criteria in a flexible way. The use cases above, including legacy support, are first-class citizens. The definition of a Classification API is out of scope. Ideally, whichever classification API or project is adopted by the Neutron project as a whole will be the one chosen to interact with the herein proposed SFC API, e.g. the neutron-classifier [7]. Data Model Impact ----------------- .. image:: ../../images/sfc-model.png The idea with a model like this is to map Service Function Chains, Service Functions, Classification Rule Sets and optionally Metadata Actions together, thus creating a directed graph with all the SFs part of a chain (nodes), and how to reach them through different classification criteria (edges). It does not mean that the actual act of classifying traffic will take place at each and every hop, but that logical classification definitions will influence the next hop at any point during the chain. The backend/driver implementation of the API should have the logic to instantiate classification actions at the appropriate points of the chain, where the next hop is ambiguous due to possibly different classifications of traffic that can be matched. This is essentially Reclassification and Branching. The resource expected to be generated inside as a product of relating the base constructs with each other, defines a unique hop in the SFC graph. Specifically, one hop will uniquely identify the reachability of one Service Function inside a specific Service Function Path. Service Function Path [4] information is contained inside the enabled SFC Encapsulation protocol for a specific SFC and identifies one of the multiple paths in the graph [6] represented by the SFC, as well as where in the path the specific SFC-encapsulated packet is. Although the glue of these resources is the Service Path Hop resource, the definition of that glue is made through the Service Function Chain resource, as can be seen in the API examples section closer to the end of the document. Below is an example of the high-level view of a SFC defined through this API: .. image:: ../../images/sfc-example.png The Service Function C node has multiple circles inside with the letter "I", since it is an example that denotes that there can be various instances able to provide Service Function C. The selection of these will be made through an Instance Selection Policy (possibly similar to opendaylight-sfc's Scheduling Algorithms [5]), provided by the API herein proposed. This is what enables Elasticity and Load Balancing for Service Functions. As mentioned earlier, having specific classifications associated with specific hops of the SFC graph does not mean the act of classifying traffic will take place at each and every of these hops. Without SFC encapsulation ("legacy" mode) it will happen since there is no generic attribute in the packet that carries the type of traffic (independently of being L2/3/4/7). With SFC encapsulation, the act of classifying traffic will only occur if the next hop SF would be ambiguous due to multiple possible traffic classification criteria. For example, in the figure above, some kind of classification will need to occur after Service Function A sends the traffic back to the logical service function forwarder (SFF). How exactly that will be done depends on the backend/driver implementation of the API. However, when Service Function B sends the traffic back to the logical SFF, no classification will be necessary, since it is non-ambiguous what the next Service Function should be. It is assumed that all traffic exiting from Service Function B, of a specific Service Function Path is of a specific classification, and only a single SF next hop is possible, which is Service Function D. This is not the same as selecting a specific instance within a specific SF, as that is influenced by the Instance Selection Policy (different selections of instances should not alter the Service Function Path in any way, only change where packets are steered to in practice). Possible Architecture --------------------- Although this spec is focused on the API, it is beneficial to explain the thinking behind it in terms of a possible architecture and layering with different components. .. image:: ../../images/sfc-arch.png This architecture is not officially part of the initial API proposal, but is rather one possible way of leveraging the API and be able to interact with different backends such as: Open vSwitch, OpenDaylight, OVN, ONOS, etc. The API consumer, who can be an NFV Orchestrator, a similar higher-level northbound client or "a person", will call the API that is being proposed here. The "SFC Plugin" will take the resource definitions in, persist them in the Neutron's database and, with the help of the correct "EncapsulationTypeDriver" that is able to deploy the SFC specified in the API, will generate the hop-by-hop resources (Service Path Hop) and associate specific Service Function Path information for these hops. The logic for generating and managing the SFP information are what's in the core of an Encapsulation Type Driver. The "SFC Driver" announces what kinds of Encapsulations they support, and gets the hop mappings from the plugin. The list of available Encapsulations in the plugin come from the loaded Encapsulation Type Drivers and these should be standardized upstream. The driver is the southbound of the full SFC solution for Neutron. The driver acts as the bridge between the SFC solution and the northbound of specialized SDN-capable software or hardware, such as projects like Open vSwitch, OpenDaylight, OVN or ONOS. The driver will include all necessary logic to properly convert the mappings stored at the SFC Plugin level to constructs that the backend understands. Given the heterogeneity of the SDN controllers and networking switches today, this driver may have to do more work than the remaining SFC parts above it. The SFC API may return the Service Function Path mappings that have been generated via the SFC Plugin + Encapsulation Type Driver, to the API caller. One of the advantages of this is that an upper entity that spans the management or orchestration of other resources not strictly in Neutron, can feed consistent information to these other resources. To illustrate, consider the case where an NFVO is the consumer of the API. It it will be able to feed the Service Function Path information to a VNF Manager so that the latter can inject specific policy associated with specific hops of the Service Function Chain to the VNFs/SFs it manages. This further improves on the SFC Encapsulation consistency between the NFVO, VNFM and the VNFs themselves. The architecture for the final implementation will be addressed as a follow-up spec. The above is simply a possible one that we think makes sense, but is meant to gather feedback and further improvements towards a final version. REST API Impact --------------- Since the core of this spec is to introduce an API model for achieving an IETF-compliant SFC in a way that can coexist with the Neutron core API, a few examples of API calls (JSON payload), in their current incarnation, are provided below. They illustrate the full workflow of creating 1 SFC similar to the example diagram above but without Service Function D and E, and with 2 instances for one of the SFs. Neutron ports are assumed to exist already. No assumption is made about what is connected to those ports or whether they are part of the same subnet. Classification Rules ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ Even though this resource is out of scope, it is a dependency of the SFC API, and important to provide a few examples of such classifications rules with our take at how they can be defined:: POST /classification/rules { // autogenerated id: ipsec_ipv4_uuid "classification_rule": { "name": "ipsec_ipv4", "type": "ip", "definition": { "version": "4", "protocol": "50" // IPSec ESP "src_addr": "", "dst_addr": "", // (...) } } } POST /classification/rules { // autogenerated id: ipsec_ipv6_uuid "classification_rule": { "name": "ipsec_ipv6", "type": "ip", "definition": { "version": "6", "protocol": "50" // IPSec ESP // (...) } } } POST /classification/rules { // autogenerated id: tcp_uuid "classification_rule": { "name": "tcp", "type": "tcp", // this field or the attributes inside can be // removed since nothing is being defined "definition": { "src_port": "", "dst_port": "", "flags": "", "flags_mask": "", "reserved": "", "reserved_mask": "", "urgent_pointer": "", "min_window": "", "max_window": "", "options": "", "options_mask": "", "padding": "" } } } POST /classification/rules { // autogenerated id: udp_uuid "classification_rule": { "name": "udp", "type": "udp" } } Classification Rule Sets ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ Definition of Classification Rule Sets (based on Classification Rules provided by an hypothetical Classification API within Neutron or extensions):: POST /sfc/classification_rule_sets { // autogenerated id: ipsec_classif_rule_set_uuid "classification_rule_set": { "name": "ipsec_classification_rule_set", "classification-rules": [ "ipsec_ipv4_uuid", "ipsec_ipv6_uuid" ] } } POST /sfc/classification_rule_sets { // autogenerated id: tcp_classif_rule_set_uuid "classification_rule_set": { "name": "tcp_classification_rule_set", "classification-rules": [ "tcp_uuid" ] } } POST /sfc/classification_rule_sets { // autogenerated id: udp_classif_rule_set_uuid "classification_rule_set": { "name": "udp_classification_rule_set", "classification-rules": [ "udp_uuid" ] } } Service Functions ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ Definition of Abstract Service Functions:: POST /sfc/service_functions { // autogenerated id: ipsec_sa_uuid "service_function": { "name": "ipsec_sa", "description": "IPSec Security Gateway", "instance_selection_policy": "flow_based" } } POST /sfc/service_functions { // autogenerated id: tcp_optimizer_uuid "service_function": { "name": "tcp_optimizer", "description": "TCP Optimizer", "instance_selection_policy": "flow_based" } } POST /sfc/service_functions { // autogenerated id: basic_function_uuid "service_function": { "name": "basic_function", "description": "Another Service Function", "instance_selection_policy": "flow_based" } } Definition of Service Function Instances:: POST /sfc/service_functions { // autogenerated id: instance_ipsec_sa_uuid "service_function": { "name": "instance_ipsec_sa", "abstract_service_function": "ipsec_sa_uuid", "sfc_aware": "true", // only relevant when associated SFC // has an SFC encapsulation, i.e. non-legacy SFC. "ingress": { "locator": "ipsec_instance_neutron_port_uuid", // this should be the uuid of the neutron port that represents // the ingress point of the service function instance. "transport": "ethernet", "params": "" // a transport might require additional parameters // e.g. UDP port if none default is used. }, "egress": {} // if empty defaults to same as ingress. } } POST /sfc/service_functions { // autogenerated id: instance_tcp_optimizer_uuid "service_function": { "name": "instance_tcp_optimizer", "abstract_service_function": "tcp_optimizer_uuid", // ... similar to instance_ipsec_sa_uuid ... } } POST /sfc/service_functions { // autogenerated id: instance_basic_function_uuid "service_function": { "name": "instance_basic_function", "abstract_service_function": "basic_function_uuid", // ... similar to instance_ipsec_sa_uuid ... } } POST /sfc/service_functions { // autogenerated id: second_instance_basic_function_uuid "service_function": { "name": "second_instance_basic_function", "abstract_service_function": "basic_function_uuid", // ... similar to instance_ipsec_sa_uuid ... } } Metadata Actions ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ Definition of optional Metadata Actions to be injected by the backend:: POST /sfc/metadata_actions { // autogenerated id: md_suspicious_uuid "metadata_action": { "name": "md_suspicious", "tlv-class": 63, "type": 3, "value": "true" } } Service Function Chains ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ Definition of the Service Function Chain:: POST /sfc/service_function_chains { // returns autogenerated id: branching_chain_uuid "service_function_chain": { "name": "branching_chain", "enabled": "true", "bidirectional": "false", "sfc_encapsulation": "nsh", "hops": [ { "classification_rule_set": "ipsec_classif_rule_set_uuid", "dst_service_function": "ipsec_sa_uuid" }, { "classification_rule_set": "tcp_classif_rule_set_uuid", "src_service_function": "ipsec_sa_uuid", "dst_service_function": "tcp_optimizer_uuid" }, { "classification_rule_set": "udp_classif_rule_set_uuid", "src_service_function": "ipsec_sa_uuid", "dst_service_function": "basic_function_uuid", "metadata_actions": ["md_suspicious_uuid"] } ] } } Command Line Client Impact -------------------------- Classification Rules:: [autogenerated id: "ipsec_ipv4_uuid"] classification-rule-create --name "ipsec_ipv4" --type "ip" --definition version=4, protocol=50 // IPSec: Encapsulating Security Payload (ESP) transport mode [autogenerated id: "ipsec_ipv6_uuid"] classification-rule-create --name "ipsec_ipv6" --type "ip" --definition version=6, protocol=50 [autogenerated id: "tcp_uuid"] classification-rule-create --name "tcp" --type "tcp" // not specifying a definition means wildcarding for this protocol [autogenerated id: "udp_uuid"] classification-rule-create --name "udp" --type "udp" Classification Rule Sets:: [autogenerated id: "ipsec_uuid"] classification-rule-set-create --name "ipsec" --classification-rule ipsec_ipv4_uuid --classification-rule ipsec_ipv6_uuid [autogenerated id: "tcp_uuid"] classification-rule-set-create --name "tcp" --classification tcp_cr_uuid [autogenerated id: "udp_uuid"] classification-rule-set-create --name "udp" --classification udp_cr_uuid Service Functions:: [autogenerated id: "ipsec_sa_uuid"] service-function-create --name "ipsec_sa" --description "IPSec Security Gateway" --instance-selection-policy "flow_based" [autogenerated id: "tcp_optimizer_uuid"] service-function-create --name "tcp_optimizer" --description "TCP Optimizer" --instance-selection-policy "flow_based" [autogenerated id: "basic_function_uuid"] service-function-create --name "basic_function" --description "Another Service Function" --instance-selection-policy "flow_based" [autogenerated id: "ipsec_instance_uuid"] service-function-create --name "instance_ipsec_sa" --instance-of "ipsec_sa_uuid" --sfc-aware "true" --ingress locator=ipsec_instance_neutron_port_uuid, transport=ethernet [autogenerated id: "instance_tcp_optimizer_uuid"] service-function-create --name "instance_tcp_optimizer" --instance-of "instance_tcp_optimizer" --sfc-aware "true" --ingress locator=instance_tcp_optimizer_neutron_port_uuid, transport=ethernet [autogenerated id: "instance_basic_function_uuid"] service-function-create --name "instance_basic_function" --instance-of "basic_function_uuid" --sfc-aware "true" --ingress locator=instance_basic_function_neutron_port_uuid, transport=ethernet [autogenerated id: "second_instance_basic_function_uuid"] service-function-create --name "second_instance_basic_function" --instance-of "basic_function_uuid" --sfc-aware "true" --ingress locator=second_instance_basic_function_neutron_port_uuid, transport=ethernet Service Function Chains:: [autogenerated id: "branching_chain_uuid"] service-function-chain-create --name "branching_chain_uuid" --sfc-encapsulation "nsh" --hop classification_rule_set=ipsec_classif_rule_set_uuid, dst_service_function=ipsec_sa_uuid --hop classification_rule_set=tcp_classif_rule_set_uuid, src_service_function=ipsec_sa_uuid, dst_service_function=tcp_optimizer_uuid --hop classification_rule_set=udp_classif_rule_set_uuid, src_service_function=ipsec_sa_uuid, dst_service_function=basic_function_uuid // abstract SF with 2 instances metadata_actions=md_suspicious_uuid Security Impact --------------- None Notifications Impact -------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ None IPv6 Impact ----------- None Other Deployer Impact --------------------- Deployers may need to configure specific options depending on the the SFC plugin enabled. This is out of scope of this document. Developer Impact ---------------- None Community Impact ---------------- The introduction of an IETF-compliant SFC API will allow SFC to be used in a controller/backend independent manner. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- * igordcard Work Items ---------- * Versioned DB objects for: * ServiceFunctionChain * ClassificationRuleSet * MetadataAction * ServiceFunction * ServiceFunctionInstance * AbstractServiceFunction * SFC API endpoint implementation * Client changes to enable SFC API * SFC plugin implementation (to be covered in separate spec) * TBD Dependencies ============ API-tests --------- TBD Functional Tests ---------------- Functional tests will be defined as part of the SFC plugin implementation and are out of scope of this spec. Full Stack Tests ---------------- Full stack tests will be defined as part of the SFC plugin implementation and are out of scope of this spec. Documentation Impact ==================== User Documentation ------------------ The existing Networking Guide will be extended for this feature. The existing `CLI guide <https://github.com/openstack/openstack-manuals/blob/master/doc/cli-reference/source/neutron.rst>`_ will be updated for this feature. Developer Documentation ----------------------- A new `SFC devref <https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/master/doc/source/devref/sfc.rst>`_ will be created for this feature. API Documentation ----------------- API documentation will be added for this feature. References ========== [1] http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/networking-sfc [2] https://datatracker.ietf.org/wg/sfc/documents [3] http://www.etsi.org/deliver/etsi_gs/nfv/001_099/002/01.01.01_60/gs_nfv002v010101p.pdf [4] https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/rfc7665/?include_text=1 [5] https://github.com/opendaylight/docs/blob/a34188569b88e9214876751ebfb7d7f2650aaa38/manuals/user-guide/src/main/asciidoc/sfc/odl-sfc-sf-scheduler-user.adoc [6] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Path_(graph_theory) [7] https://github.com/openstack/neutron-classifier

be able to specify which l3 agent will have high priority to

If the master l3 agent is alive, it will host the active instance

If the master l3 agent is not alive, the rest non-master l3 agents
will elect one l3 agent to host the active instance of a HA router.
The result of this election is random, just as the behaviour of HA
router without this feature.

commit_message:
Enhance L3Scheduler for active HA router

Currently, the "active" instance of a HA router is determined randomly
by keepalived process.

The spec proposes to enhance L3Scheduler to let neutron select a l3 agent
to host the "active" instance of a HA router.

Co-Authored-By: gongysh <gong.yongsheng@99cloud.net>

Change-Id: I36955dd1eac994a2ed9897122ce71beba7758fbf
Implements: blueprint select-active-l3-agent
Partial-Bug: #1370033
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron-specs refs/changes/99/257299/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ===================================================== Select l3 agent to host the active HA router ===================================================== :Author: Hong Hui Xiao <xiaohhui@cn.ibm.com> :Co-Author: gongysh <gong.yongsheng@99cloud.net> URL of launchpad blueprint: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/neutron/+spec/select-active-l3-agent RFE: https://bugs.launchpad.net/neutron/+bug/1370033 Today, HA routers are hosted across multiple L3 agents. For each router, only one l3 agent(determined automatically) will host the "active" instance of HA router, and all the rest l3 agents will host the "standby" instances of HA router. Automatic determination can create issues during development and routine maintenance. The feature here would allow the administrator to manually select a l3 agent to host the "active" instance HA router. Operators could use it to force the instance of a HA router in an agent to change from "active" to "standby" as preparation for a maintenance window. Developers could use it as part of testing. Problem Description =================== Having multiple L3-agents/Network-nodes helps us in load sharing, but not for High-availability. L3 HA would address the High Availability use-cases where the same router is scheduled on multiple Network nodes with one acting as Master and the others in Backup state. If the Master HA router goes down, the backup node would take over the role of Master. For some reasons, the administrator wants to schedule the Master HA Router to a particular Network node. Some of the reasons behind this requirement could be: 1. The chosen network node might have better processing power compared to the other network nodes. 2. The external connectivity on the Network node could be better compared to the other nodes. 3. Even if HA routers are hosted by multiple L3 agents, the traffic may not distributed equally among these agents. For example, one l3 agent is always active for all HA routers, others are all standby. 4. Any other reasons you can think of... Currently there is no straight forward option for administrator to do such job. Proposed Change =============== Add one attribute to Router. This attribute represents that which l3 agent will have high priority to host the "active" instance of HA router. The l3 agent in this attribute will be called prior l3 agent in the following text. This prior l3 agent doesn't have to be the one that host the "active" instance of HA router. But it can win the elect against other l3 agents to host the "active" instance of HA router. Administrator can specify this attribute when creating HA router. The l3 agent will host the "active" instance of HA router, when the HA router is scheduled to l3 agents at the first time. Administrator can update this attribute for a HA router. The old l3 agent in the attribute will become a normal l3 agent for the HA router. And the new specified l3 agent will become the prior l3 agent for the HA router. Restart signal will be sent to keepalived process to consume the change in configuration file. The "priority" and "preempt" in keepalived will be used under the hood. But it doesn't mean that this blueprint will expose these configurations to users. Among the l3 agents that host HA router, only prior l3 agent will have higher "priority" in the keepalived configuration. The prior l3 agent may go down for some reason, for example shutting down the host. The "preempt" will make sure prior l3 agent takes over the "active" instance of HA router, when the l3 agent is back alive. The current mechanism of reporting status of instances of a HA router, will still be used and will not be changed. User will still need to use "neutron l3-agent-list-hosting-router <router>" to check which l3 agent hosts the "active" instance of HA router. The prior l3 agent must be limited by neutron Availability Zone or any other limitations. An un-qualified value for prior l3 agent will lead to exception at POST and PUT Router. And prior l3 agent is only available for HA routers. The prior l3 agent for Router will deault to be None, which means there is no prior l3 agent for this HA router. Under this circumstance, the HA router will act just as current neutron. Data Model Impact ----------------- As noted above, the spec adds prior_l3_agent attribute to DB. A migration script will be provided. Attribute will be added: prior_l3_agent attribute to RouterExtraAttributes .. csv-table:: :header: Attribute,Type,Description prior_l3_agent, String, the UUID of l3 agent that will have high priority to host the HA router REST API Impact --------------- * /routers The following attribute is added. .. csv-table:: New attribute :header: Attribute Name,Type,Access,Default Value,Validation Conversion,Description prior_l3_agent,string,"RW(POST and PUT), all",N/A,string of UUID,UUID of l3 agent Security Impact --------------- Only admin can invoke this API, which is enforced in policy.json. Notifications Impact -------------------- None Other End User Impact --------------------- python-neutronclient will support new prior_l3_agent value. Performance Impact ------------------ None IPv6 Impact ----------- None. This proposal is protocol agnostic. Other Deployer Impact --------------------- None Upgrade Impact --------------------- Before the upgrade, all HA routers are considered to have prior_l3_agent as None. Administrator can update this attribute to other values. Developer Impact ---------------- None Community Impact ---------------- None Alternatives ------------ One possible alternative is to remove HA router from all l3 agents except the one that is wished to host "active" instance of HA router, by using "neutron l3-agent-router-remove <agent_id> <router>". After the removal, and the HA router in the only left l3 agent is in "active" state, add HA router back to the l3 agents that are wished to host "standby" instances of HA router, by using "neutron l3-agent-router-add <agent_id> <router>". In this solution, namespace will be destroyed and rebuilded during the procedure, this is a bit over-kill for a normal operation. And administrator has to do these extra operation, instead of just designating one l3 agent to host the "active" instance of HA router, at creating router. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: Hong Hui Xiao <xiaohhui@cn.ibm.com> Secondary assignee: ZongKai LI <lizklibj@cn.ibm.com> Work Items ---------- * Add prior_l3_agent to DB models * Change l3 scheduler to bind Router and prior_l3_agent * Change neutronclient to consume the new attribute * Notify router update when prior_l3_agent of a HA router changes * Update in l3 agent to consume the new attribute Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= Tempest Tests ------------- None Functional Tests ---------------- Add tests, which ensure the functionality mentioned in this spec are achieved. API Tests --------- Tests for the new attribute Documentation Impact ==================== User Documentation ------------------ The use case and usage will be documented in the defref. Developer Documentation ----------------------- None References ========== https://github.com/acassen/keepalived https://blueprints.launchpad.net/neutron/+spec/add-availability-zone

subject: Add linux-image-extra-virtual to host packages
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-06-29 19:55:04.000000000', 'files': ['vars/ubuntu-14.04.yml', 'vars/ubuntu-16.04.yml'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-openstack_hosts/commit/27c0ee1e47eca31740a81a59ed325d6dbce3be17', 'message': 'Add linux-image-extra-virtual to host packages

It appears that some Ubuntu 14.04 images only contain the base kernel package
and leave out the extra drivers package, linux-image-extra-$(uname -r).
If this package is not installed, openstack-ansible playbooks will fail on
modprobing kernel modules that are not installed (i.e. vhost_net.ko).
linux-image-extra-virtual should provide the linux-image-extra package for
currently installed base kernel package.

Change-Id: If2f008357117495c9e4b80dbfef68503fa93a809
Closes-Bug: 1595323
'}]
commit_message:
Add linux-image-extra-virtual to host packages

It appears that some Ubuntu 14.04 images only contain the base kernel package
and leave out the extra drivers package, linux-image-extra-$(uname -r).
If this package is not installed, openstack-ansible playbooks will fail on
modprobing kernel modules that are not installed (i.e. vhost_net.ko).
linux-image-extra-virtual should provide the linux-image-extra package for
currently installed base kernel package.

Change-Id: If2f008357117495c9e4b80dbfef68503fa93a809
Closes-Bug: 1595323
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-openstack_hosts refs/changes/50/335650/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Capture haproxy status in snapshots

This change adds the haproxy status to the command output captured on
the controllers. This will help in researching the status of the various
services when the snapshot is generated.

Change-Id: I0a7c83c21805dbd1182ea74692d76e9a49300bb8
Closes-Bug: #1570982

subject: Stop looking for master once latest seqno found
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-06-15 22:31:36.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/fuel-library/commit/d4cb2eae1c3dfd4b7044afbe48a6376908ab7502', 'message': "Fix incorrect mysql split brain determination

As part of the bootstrap process for galera, we can get in to a
state where the original master node thinks it gets in a splitbrain
condition after the the other two nodes bootstrap each other. This
change adds a check before the split brain determination to make sure
that the node isn't already current based on the GTID/SEQNUM.

What happened is node 1 is created and has the --wsrep-new-cluster
parameter, node 2 syncs from node 1. Node 3 joins and syncs from node 2.
Then when they try and fully form a quorum, we pull the GTID from all
the nodes and since they are all identical, the last node is considered
a canidate to be a master. Without this change, we would then check if
the node is a new cluster (has the --wsrep-new-cluster option) and then
return a generic error which would mean the node would try and resync.
With this change, we check to make sure that we aren't already
consistent before going down the path of assuming it's a new cluster.

Change-Id: Iacbd2e2ec403985a1ff52880669b1bec62dbbaba
Closes-Bug: #1592401

This change updates how we look for a master by stopping once we have
found a service with the largest seqno. Previously if all servers
had the same seqno then we would return the last server as a master
rather than the first. This had the side effect that during bootstrap
when the first server was the original master, it would be demoted for
each new server that was added to the group.  This should prevent the
ocf script from shuffling masters if they have the same seqno. We will
always pick the first server rather than the last.

Change-Id: Iacbd2e2ec403985a1ff52880669b1bec62dbbaba
Closes-Bug: #1592401
Related-Bug: #1592819
'}]
commit_message:
Stop looking for master once latest seqno found

This change updates how we look for a master by stopping once we have
found a service with the largest seqno. Previously if all servers
had the same seqno then we would return the last server as a master
rather than the first. This had the side effect that during bootstrap
when the first server was the original master, it would be demoted for
each new server that was added to the group.  This should prevent the
ocf script from shuffling masters if they have the same seqno. We will
always pick the first server rather than the last.

Change-Id: Iacbd2e2ec403985a1ff52880669b1bec62dbbaba
Closes-Bug: #1592401
Related-Bug: #1592819
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-library refs/changes/54/330254/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: local MYGTID MYGTID=$(get_node_gtid $HOSTNAME) if [ "${GTID}" = "${MYGTID}"]; then ocf_log info "${LH} My GTID (${MYGTID}) matches latest GTID (${GTID}), I'm cool." return 0 fi

commit_message:
Retire puppet-openstack-release-tools

An announcement was done on openstack-dev.
This project is not useful anymore since we now manage Puppet modules
releases with OpenStack Releases team, so this repo is not used anymore.
Let's retire it and do some cleanup.

commit_message:
Leave the default value of min_ttl up to the service

The previous default, 'None', would error out with oslo_config
expecting an integer value.

ERROR designate ConfigFileValueError:
 Value for option min_ttl is not valid:
 invalid literal for int() with base 10: 'None'

Change-Id: I056c7fff1607b6e7b9153ed7df4868900dc5ae44

commit_message:
Update Gemfile to work in gate

Puppet-lint v1.1.0 (the most recent release in the 1.x series) has a
crashing bug, so we were depending on puppet-lint HEAD. On 2016-06-22,
puppet-lint v2.0.0 was released, so puppet-lint HEAD is now in the v2
series. But puppet-lint_variable_contains_upcase depends on puppet-lint
v1, so puppet-lint HEAD no longer satisfies our dependencies.

This patch pins the version of puppet-lint to the commit immediately
before the v2.0.0 release, so we get the bug fix and satisfy
puppet-lint_variable_contains_upcase's dependencies.

Change-Id: I3eab1b883a3dc5ca5d02d4c71b97507d36d7f349
Closes-bug: #1597849

commit_message:
Only use Timeout if we don't have a final_resp

I'm sure the Timeout context manager is relatively cheap, but it can't
be free.

Change-Id: I71c0c5944ec372e9b983021dd024de0c5aa1ded2

Added watcher package ensure

Watcher package is available now for RedHat and Debian (experimental
repo).

Note: Watcher package is not available in Ubuntu repository.

commit_message:
[doc/api]Remove space within word

Following two words should not have space.
 X-Subject-Token
 X-Auth-Token
But currently these two words have CR within these words,
This causes redundunt spaces.

http://developer.openstack.org/api-ref/identity/v3/authenticate-v3.html

Change-Id: I3ae39cdaf19b73b5f7750eeb9b01d1447e2ca73a

added_lines: """Memorize metaclass for SSHClient This class implements caching and managing of SSHClient connections. Class is not in public scope: all required interfaces is accessible throw SSHClient classmethods. Main flow is: SSHClient() -> check for cached connection and if exists the same: check for alive, reconnect if required and return if exists with different credentials: delete and continue processing create new connection and cache on success Close cached connections is allowed per-client and all stored: connection will be closed, but still stored in cache for faster reconnect Clear cache is strictly not recommended: from this moment all open connections should be managed manually, duplicates is possible. """ """Hostname access for backward compatibility :rtype: str """

commit_message:
Revert "Pre-install pip/virtualenv packages"

This reverts commit a85ce75d6bf720cce0101a3cdfa09c90ef1d156e.

Hitting issues on dsvm jobs when removing python-virtualenv and installing it again with pip:

http://logs.openstack.org/35/332435/6/check/gate-ansible-role-cloud-launcher-dsvm-ansible-func-centos-7/d8ef6d6/

Reproduced the issue here:

http://paste.openstack.org/show/525953/

Change-Id: Id99a3dfb4f086f3927d633e565e2084a35175178
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/diskimage-builder refs/changes/77/337677/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: python /tmp/get-pip.py pip install virtualenv
deleted_lines: if [[ $DISTRO_NAME =~ (centos|fedora) ]]; then # GENERAL WARNING : mixing packaged python libraries with # pip-installed versions always creates issues. Upstream # openstack-infra uses this a lot (especially devstack) but be # warned: here be dragons :) # Firstly we want to install the system packages. Otherwise later # on somebody does a "yum install python-virtualenv" and goes and # overwrites the pip installed version with the packaged version, # leading to all sorts of weird version issues. ${YUM} install -y python-virtualenv python-pip python-setuptools # install pip; this overwrites packaged pip python /tmp/get-pip.py # pip and setuptools are closely related; we want to ensure the # latest for sanity. Because distro packages don't include enough # info in the egg for pip to be certain it has fully uninstalled # the old package, for safety we clear it out by hand (this seems # to have been a problem with very old to new updates, # e.g. centos6 to current-era, but less so for smaller jumps). # There is a bit of chicken-and-egg problem with pip in that it # requires setuptools for some operations, such as wheel creation. # But just installing setuptools shouldn't require setuptools # itself, so we are safe for this small section. rm -rf /usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/setuptools* pip install -U setuptools # now install latest virtualenv. it vendors stuff it needs so # doesn't have issues with other system packages. pip install -U virtualenv # Add this to exclude so that we don't install a later package # over it if it updates. Note that fedora-minimal, bootstrapped # via yum, can have an old yum.conf around, so look for dnf first. if [[ -f /etc/dnf/dnf.conf ]]; then conf=/etc/dnf/dnf.conf elif [[ -f /etc/yum.conf ]]; then conf=/etc/yum.conf else die "No conf to modify?" fi echo "exclude=python-virtualenv,python-pip,python-setuptools" >> ${conf} else python /tmp/get-pip.py pip install virtualenv fi

commit_message:
Pre-install pip/virtualenv packages

If we're installing pip/virtualenv from source, we need to make sure
we pre-install the packaged versions before the upstream
versions. Otherwise, CI jobs later on that depend on packaged versions
of pip/virtualenv can bring them in and overwrite the upstream
versions we have installed, which leads to a heck of a mess and
usually very confusing failures.

I have also moved in a small hack from system-config:install_puppet.sh
that we found was necessary when using pip versions from upstream.

Note this is not as much of an issue on Debian/Ubuntu, as they keep
their pip packages in a separate place to the system packages, so you
don't have these overwite conflicts as much.

Change-Id: Ib40708c07b939b84661c44df88a5a308fd0c7216
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/diskimage-builder refs/changes/72/327472/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

Upstream # openstack-infra uses this a lot (especially devstack) but be # warned: here be dragons :) # Firstly we want to install the system packages. Otherwise later # on somebody does a "yum install python-virtualenv" and goes and # overwrites the pip installed version with the packaged version, # leading to all sorts of weird version issues. ${YUM} install -y python-virtualenv python-pip python-setuptools # install pip; this overwrites packaged pip python /tmp/get-pip.py # pip and setuptools are closely related; we want to ensure the # latest for sanity. Because distro packages don't include enough # info in the egg for pip to be certain it has fully uninstalled # the old package, for safety we clear it out by hand (this seems # to have been a problem with very old to new updates, # e.g. centos6 to current-era, but less so for smaller jumps). # There is a bit of chicken-and-egg problem with pip in that it # requires setuptools for some operations, such as wheel creation. # But just installing setuptools shouldn't require setuptools # itself, so we are safe for this small section. rm -rf /usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/setuptools* pip install -U setuptools # now install latest virtualenv. it vendors stuff it needs so # doesn't have issues with other system packages. pip install -U virtualenv else python /tmp/get-pip.py pip install virtualenv fi

commit_message:
Migrate from xmlbuilder to custom builder based on xml.etree

blueprint fuel-qa-python3-compatibility

Change-Id: I9388023e20f7f4d231739c7e9423835a10c3ed0c
(cherry picked from commit 892a828)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-devops refs/changes/91/337491/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Copyright 2016 Mirantis, Inc. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. from xml.dom import minidom from xml.etree import ElementTree as ET import six class XMLGeneratorElement(object): def __init__(self, name, parent, builder): self.elem = ET.SubElement(parent, name) self.parent = parent self.builder = builder self.prev_elem = None def __enter__(self): self.prev_elem = self.builder.curr_el self.builder.curr_el = self.elem def __exit__(self, *args): self.builder.curr_el = self.prev_elem self.prev_elem = None def __getattr__(self, name): return XMLGeneratorElement( name=name, parent=self.elem, builder=self.builder) def __call__(self, txt=None, **kwargs): # update attributes kwargs = {k: str(v) for k, v in kwargs.items()} self.elem.attrib.update(kwargs) # update text if any if txt: self.elem.text = str(txt) return self @six.python_2_unicode_compatible class XMLGenerator(object): def __init__(self, root_name, **kwargs): self.root = ET.Element(root_name) kwargs = {k: str(v) for k, v in kwargs.items()} self.root.attrib.update(kwargs) self.curr_el = self.root def __getattr__(self, name): return XMLGeneratorElement( name=name, parent=self.curr_el, builder=self) def __str__(self): rough_string = ET.tostring(self.root, encoding='utf-8') reparsed = minidom.parseString(rough_string) s = reparsed.toprettyxml(indent=' ', encoding='utf-8') if six.PY2: return s else: return str(s, encoding='utf-8')

commit_message:
Add Neutron port scenario

Add a new scenario to test supplying fixed IP address information
when updating a Neutron Port.

Change-Id: I204bcd555b28f18f4baaed33424c9fb49d1272f0
Partial-Bug: #1597783
Signed-off-by: Ryan Moats <rmoats@us.ibm.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/rally refs/changes/59/336059/9 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: @validation.number("ports_per_network", minval=1, integer_only=True) @validation.required_services(consts.Service.NEUTRON) @validation.required_openstack(users=True) @scenario.configure(context={"cleanup": ["neutron"]}) def create_and_update_ports_in_subnet(self, port_update_args, subnet_cidr_start, network_create_args=None, subnet_create_args=None, port_create_args=None, ports_per_network=None): """Create and update a given number of ports within a subnet. Measure the "neutron port-create" and "neutron port-update" commands performance when the update involves manipulating ip addresses (which require subnets) :param port_update_args: dict, PUT /v2.0/ports update request options :param subnet_cidr_start: str, start value for subnets CIDR :param network_create_args: dict, POST /v2.0/networks request options. Deprecated. :param subnet_create_args: dict, POST /v2.0/subnets request options :param port_create_args: dict, POST /v2.0/ports request options :param ports_per_network: int, number of ports for one network """ network = self._get_or_create_network(network_create_args) subnets_per_network = 1 subnets = self._create_subnets(network, subnet_create_args, subnet_cidr_start, subnets_per_network) port_update_args{"fixed_ips"} = [ { "subnet_id": subnets[0]["id"] } ] for i in range(ports_per_network): port = self._create_port(network, port_create_args) self._update_port(port, port_update_args)

commit_message:
Change the data type of scheduler_default_filters to bool if empty

Puppet-nova expects an array of filters or false (boolean) for the
configuration scheduler_default_filters (nova.conf).
If scheduler_default_filters is not set from THT, then a data type
conversion is required, so that the default value is treated as
boolean 'false'.

Change-Id: I17bafbc0b5deb82b2c2b3c74aa994d4fce0a90cc
Implements: blueprint tripleo-ovs-dpdk
Signed-off-by: karthik s <ksundara@redhat.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-tripleo refs/changes/62/337262/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: $sch_def_filters = hiera('nova::scheduler::filter::scheduler_default_filters','') if empty ($sch_def_filters) { $scheduler_default_filters = str2bool ('false') class { '::nova::scheduler::filter': scheduler_default_filters => $scheduler_default_filters, } } else { include ::nova::scheduler::filter }

commit_message:
quickstart.sh fails due to missing redhat-rpm-config

On clean systems quickstart.sh may fail on installing pip dependencies
due to missing redhat-rpm-config. This change add redhat-rpm-config to
quickstart.sh in install_deps().

Change-Id: Ie91183f1165b4843ff2e10fa06db310547f0c07e
Closes-Bug: 1598573

commit_message:
Return current router if there are no updates

The update_router() method currently returns None if there are
not updates to be applied, but this is a bug as *some* router
dict is expected to be returned (e.g., the os_router Ansible
module expects a router to be returned).

Change-Id: I50912d03bc57250110f26757d23de92cbcf8002c

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-07-05 01:51:36.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/puppet-designate/commit/e3059094bdde15ab9ace64e189a5bbb18ab1ed27', 'message': 'Fix typo that would make the package name the service name

Change-Id: I1d0b9b66b7fb5ec97d0992c2efd58b63359d364d
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2016-07-05 02:41:55.000000000', 'files': ['manifests/pool_manager.pp', 'manifests/params.pp'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/puppet-designate/commit/5dcd51eca2c5b14aa4bbb775ccdb2a8581389f94', 'message': 'Fix typo that would make the package name the service name

Additionally, the package name for "designate-pool-manager" is
"designate-pool-manager" in Ubuntu Cloud Archive [1]. Not

[1]: http://ubuntu-cloud.archive.canonical.com/ubuntu/dists/xenial-updates/newton/main/binary-amd64/Packages

Change-Id: I1d0b9b66b7fb5ec97d0992c2efd58b63359d364d

commit_message:
Fix typo that would make the package name the service name

Since the service and the package name can differ, it is important
to really choose the PACKAGE name and not the SERVICE name.
For example, in RDO, the package is
"openstack-designate-pool-manager" but the service is
"designate-pool-manager".

Additionally, the package name for "designate-pool-manager" is
"designate-pool-manager" in Ubuntu Cloud Archive [1]. Not
"openstack-designate-pool-manager".

[1]: http://ubuntu-cloud.archive.canonical.com/ubuntu/dists/xenial-updates/newton/main/binary-amd64/Packages

Change-Id: I1d0b9b66b7fb5ec97d0992c2efd58b63359d364d

commit_message:
Add env var for version cache timeout

As part of the Newton midcycle, it was discussed that it might
be nice to be able to specify the version cache timeout value
via an environment variable, rather than the current hard-coded
value.

Fixes-bug: #1596734
Change-Id: I2bc77c64b764f6c22574a30b0e5af4ca6feff29f

commit_message:
Fix bad entry points in setup.cfg

There are defined entrypoints that do not exist in the code base,
these result in `Could not load EntryPoint.parse` errors when
doing `openstack --help`.

Closes-Bug: 1597788
Change-Id: Ia28acdad53e31e43217933b5f77bf2c6d419fc2e

commit_message:
Negative tests for testing actions with Chassis

Negative tests for the Ironic CLI commands which checks actions with
chassis command like show, update, delete either using with arguments
or without arguments.

Change-Id: I7431febddbdf7b064932d208a36f99317145d5e7

Add license headers to all source files

The correct application of the Apache 2.0 license should include
headers with copyright and license information in all source
files; add headers as required to Python files.

commit_message:
Add region information to nova section

In multi-region clouds, Neutron needs to understand which Nova
region it should send notification events to, otherwise its not
able to consistently resolve the correct Nova API endpoint to
use to send port creation notifications to.

Add region_name to nova section based on configuration of charm.

Closes-Bug: 1594602

Change-Id: If4d6ba41a064bc93eaa32efcd524fea6f0891275
(cherry picked from commit 9e12acb3b8251321d6e4e71da9427b2100f7a972)

commit_message:
Fix DeepModel validation

Now it is possible to pass {validate: true}
option to DeepModel's set method to validate the model.

isValid calls are left in the code where the following
logic implemented: set new data to a model (the data can be invalid)
and then validate the model to show errors on UI

Change-Id: I5ca7ac639a34e0abae887de9d215e8c8747e37a3
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-ui refs/changes/79/334979/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: attributesModel.set({[name]: value}, {validate: true, models: this.state.configModels}); nodeAttributes.set(initialNodeAttributes, {validate: true, models: configModels});
deleted_lines: attributesModel.set(name, value); attributesModel.isValid({models: this.state.configModels}); nodeAttributes.set(initialNodeAttributes); nodeAttributes.isValid({models: configModels});

commit_message:
Fix rsyslog deprecated and duplicate settings

This change moves the 'imfile' module loading to the separate one
configuration file and fix the rsyslogd-2307 [0] in all snippets.

[0] http://www.rsyslog.com/e/2307

Change-Id: I4e90f752ccc7eddda22df082e4c6248c2c40fe9f
Closes-Bug: #1598625
Signed-off-by: Maksim Malchuk <mmalchuk@mirantis.com>

commit_message:
Gate-hook devstack post-config

Changed datasources snapshot interval(get_all) to two hours
 instead of 10 min. This is to avoid having a difference in sample time
 during tempests. Given that the tempests run in an isolated environment
 and that all changes occur from within the tempests, the change should not affect
 current tempests consistency.

Change-Id: I2c238275c8ffee0fc24915e98b49ee946a71069d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/vitrage refs/changes/75/337475/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: [[post-config|\$VITRAGE_CONF]] [datasources] snapshots_interval = 7200

commit_message:
SSHClient rework for SSH Manager integration: memorize

Memorize SSHClient with clean-up by node and global supported
Memorize uses custom metaclass
If creds changed -> connection is recreated (1 connect per host: port pair).
reduced warning messages level
clear() marked as deprecated to prevent memorization breakage

Change-Id: Ie9f3711f8be946c823c7d9feb3f3edda56257640
blueprint: sshmanager-integration
(cherry picked from commit c521d23)

added_lines: def _close_remotes(self): """Call close cached ssh connections for current node""" for network_name in {'admin', 'public', 'internal'}: try: SSHClient.close_connections( hostname=self.get_ip_address_by_network_name(network_name)) except BaseException: logger.debug( '{0}._close_remotes for {1} failed'.format( self.name, network_name)) self._close_remotes() self._close_remotes() self._close_remotes() self._close_remotes() def __del__(self): self._close_remotes()

commit_message:
List system dependencies for running common tests

Add an other-requirements.txt file containing a cross-platform list
of dependencies needed for running included tox-based tests. Also
include a tox environment for convenience calling the bindep[*]
utility to list any missing system requirements.

This change is self-testing.

For other-requirements.txt see also
http://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/drivers.html#package-requirements

[*] http://docs.openstack.org/infra/bindep/

Change-Id: Ibd031a99fb4f24f98aeba6968046c6e7a91a4430
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/release-tools refs/changes/04/335804/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: [testenv:bindep] # Do not install any requirements. We want this to be fast and work even if # system dependencies are missing, since it's used to tell you what system # dependencies are missing! This also means that bindep must be installed # separately, outside of the requirements files. deps = bindep commands = bindep test

commit_message:
Add purge flag in image_meta_to_headers

When calling image_client_v1's update_image with "purge" flag,
it raise 400 Bad Request with message "Bad header: x-image-meta-purge-props".
This is to add purge transform in image_meta_to_headers to support purge flag.

Change-Id: I2a30c2fc746701805f9e9cc77068c7eaa17dbcb8
Closes-Bug: #1597591
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tempest refs/changes/84/335784/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: purge = fields_copy.pop('purge_props', None) if purge is not None: headers['x-glance-registry-purge-props'] = purge

commit_message:
Splitting fd metadata to system and user

Currently, the fd metadata being passed to the storlet side
is a single flat dictionary, that consists of both storlet internal
system md and user md, which is swift object md.

This structure is not extendable, esp. with the additional
system metadata we need for ranges. This patch splits the
metadata into two sub dictionaries:
1. "storlets"
2. "storage"
In the future as we also pass swift sysmeta we should
further split the "storage" part to system and user.
Note, however, that this may require update to existing
storlets or introduce a new API version.

Bonus: ability to run functest in a dev / jenkins flavors
       where dev flavor skips slow tests e.g. 1GB put
       which also fills up the dev env device...
       docs are updated accordingly.

Change-Id: I88ecba46a31fa8b201ff3b50d1449aae32c7ef82

commit_message:
Use native Promises for Backbone ajax

   This change makes Backbone ajax method to use Promise instead
   of $.Deffered

Implements: blueprint native-promises

Change-Id: I2976f919c171f4887292062423117b1056af6b67
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-ui refs/changes/87/335387/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: this.overrideBackbonePromises(); return Promise.reject(); return Promise.reject(response); overrideBackbonePromises() { Backbone.ajax = function ajax() { return Promise.resolve(Backbone.$.ajax(...arguments)); }; var originalSaveMethod = Backbone.Model.prototype.save; Backbone.Model.prototype.save = function save() { var xhr = originalSaveMethod.apply(this, arguments); return (xhr !== false) ? xhr : Promise.reject(new Error('ModelError')); }; var originalDestroyMethod = Backbone.Model.prototype.destroy; Backbone.Model.prototype.destroy = function destroy() { var xhr = originalDestroyMethod.apply(this, arguments); return (xhr !== false) ? xhr : Promise.reject(new Error('ModelError')); }; }

  Other exceptions won't be caught by retry decorator.
- Added DevopsException class

commit_message:
Refactoring of retry decorator

- retry decorator was changed and now requires to specify exception class.
  Other exceptions won't be caught by retry decorator.
- Added DevopsException class
- Removed retries for minor libvirt driver methods
- Removed redundant retry on SSHClient.__connect_sftp
- Added unit test for retry decorator

Change-Id: I1aa74044c91c6ccbc92e151de3bc891866bbc662
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-devops refs/changes/96/334096/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Copyright 2013 - 2016 Mirantis, Inc.import inspectfrom devops.error import DevopsException from devops import logger def retry(exception, count=10, delay=1): """Retry decorator Retries to run decorated method with the same parameters in case of thrown :exception: :type exception: class :param exception: exception class :type count: int :param count: retry count :type delay: int :param delay: delay between retries in seconds :rtype: function """ def decorator(func): if inspect.ismethod(func): full_name = '{}:{}.{}'.format( inspect.getmodule(func.im_class).__name__, func.im_class.__name__, func.__name__) elif inspect.isfunction(func): full_name = '{}.{}'.format( inspect.getmodule(func).__name__, func.__name__) else: raise DevopsException( 'Wrong func parameter type {!r}'.format(func)) except exception as e: logger.debug( 'Exception {!r} while running {!r}. ' 'Waiting {} seconds.'.format(e, func.__name__, delay), exc_info=True) # logs traceback arg_str = ', '.join(( ', '.join(map(repr, args)), ', '.join('{}={!r}'.format(k, v) for k, v in kwargs), )) logger.debug('Retrying {}({})'.format(full_name, arg_str))
deleted_lines: # Copyright 2013 - 2014 Mirantis, Inc. def retry(count=10, delay=1): def decorator(func): # noinspection PyBroadException except Exception:

commit_message:
Maintain quotes if present at end of secure_path

When adding /usr/local/bin to secure_path place it before the closing
quote if one is present.

Change-Id: I6a37d81da1ee23170dd17125b2e6322d9a28ddbe
Closes-Bug: #1598089

commit_message:
Disable creation of nwfilters by default

- Add environment variable ENABLE_LIBVIRT_NWFILTERS, default=False.
  It will enable creation of nwfilters for network and interfaces.

Change-Id: I9d7596927933b0bc3597633d86093c3d1e417314
Closes-Bug: #1578280

Redirect error messages from libvirt to debug logger

  are skipped

commit_message:
Allow to change boot order and close tray for Node

- Added LibvirtNode.set_boot() - allows to set new boot
  order on node.
  example:
      node.set_boot(['cdrom', 'hd'])

- Added Node.close_tray() - allows to close cdrom tray.
  (Closes trays of all cdrom devices on selected node)

- Changed DevopsDriver.volume_upload - these changes allow to upload
  a new image to existing volume. If there is no enough space
  virStorageVol.resize will be called to increase size of the volume
  to be equal to size of the new image file.

- Added new helper to support proper conversion from xml to string

Change-Id: I9fb726f84d11b5d2d9d6a40ec4993ca5db520dbf
Related-Bug: #1593703
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-devops refs/changes/60/331660/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from __future__ import divisionimport mathimport xml.etree.ElementTree as ETimport sixdef bytes_to_gbytes(value): """Converts value in bytes to gigabytes NOTE: math.ceil method is applied to make result >= specified value. :type value: int :rtype: int """ return int(math.ceil(value / 1024 ** 3)) def xml_tostring(tree): """Converts ElementTree object to string :type tree: ElementTree :rtype: str """ if six.PY2: return ET.tostring(tree) else: return ET.tostring(tree, encoding='unicode')

commit_message:
Consistent ERROR messages

Capitalize ERROR for all project-config specific tests, so
that errors can found easily.

Add missing ERROR marks.

Change-Id: I1d7e1077de62945647e0329462016a34eaabd83e

will need to restart the service.

commit_message:
Increase reboot timeout to 15 mins

This change increases the reboot timeout setting from 240 seconds to
900 seconds as some hardware takes much longer to reboot than others.

Change-Id: I4d17e6c1800f108747c50eb7f29638d28ecb555e
Closes-Bug: #1594882
DocImpact: The default timeout for astute to wait for a node to be
rebooted is now 15 minutes. To manually change this, you can update the
astute.conf file and change the reboot_timeout value to the number of
seconds to wait for a reboot. After updating the configuration file, you
will need to restart the service.
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-astute refs/changes/39/332239/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: conf[:reboot_timeout] = 900 # how long it can take for node to reboot
deleted_lines: conf[:reboot_timeout] = 240 # how long it can take for node to reboot

commit_message:
Remove all jobs running on rh1

rh1 is being physically moved and possibly redeployed soon, until it
is back running stop using it. And replace a subset of the jobs with
jobs running on rh2.

Change-Id: I9e0be0cf835b9530aab951d1e5255a195d4270bf

commit_message:
Obsolete mac_generation_retries and deprecate the option

As discussed in this patch [1] this option didn't come from any actual
user-encountered problem and is now effectively obsolete for its
original purpose anyway.  In the interest of cleaning up options that
aren't of any real use, this patch obsoletes this one immediately and
marks it deprecated for removal in Ocata.

TrivalFix

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/327413

Change-Id: I58003d5b07e28c7254ff836dec937f699bc83112

commit_message:
SSHClient rework for SSH Manager integration

1. Implemented SSHAuth
2. Old initialization API has been marked as deprecated
3. SFTP is started on demand with 3 retries
4. Reworked unit test to cover 100%
5. Added docstrings
6. Remove cyclic SSH session initialization in helper
7. Code is ready for adopted memorize pattern

blueprint: sshmanager-integration

Change-Id: I49d0aa635ba3f3125ab17531c0790a0106b87fea
(cherry picked from commit aae58e2)

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-06-16 12:33:49.000000000', 'files': ['reference/user-committee-repos.yaml'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/governance/commit/2494660b0331ce38b03a8609b567323db0374629', 'message': 'Add governance-uc repo

As per mailing list discussion[1], governance.openstack.org will
become a neutral place for all of OpenStack governance reference
information (Board, TC, UC).

This change adds a repository, governance-uc, which is to contain
the content for the UC component of governance.openstack.org, and
is step one of the 5 step plan:

- Create the repository (UC, infra)
- Populate it with the data you want there (UC)
- Work with infra to publish under /uc (UC, infra)
- Propose content for the neutral page (TC, UC)
- Change openstack/governance to publish under /tc,
  set up redirects/aliases (TC, infra)

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-tc/2016-June/001223.html

Change-Id: I941f2df200da0ac714f4afcf0c9d33d2711517d1
Depends-On: I80debe64d6fbf31d23415f373adf47a7a034b7f0
'}]
commit_message:
Add governance-uc repo

As per mailing list discussion[1], governance.openstack.org will
become a neutral place for all of OpenStack governance reference
information (Board, TC, UC).

This change adds a repository, governance-uc, which is to contain
the content for the UC component of governance.openstack.org, and
is step one of the 5 step plan:

- Create the repository (UC, infra)
- Populate it with the data you want there (UC)
- Work with infra to publish under /uc (UC, infra)
- Propose content for the neutral page (TC, UC)
- Change openstack/governance to publish under /tc,
  set up redirects/aliases (TC, infra)

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-tc/2016-June/001223.html

Change-Id: I941f2df200da0ac714f4afcf0c9d33d2711517d1
Depends-On: I80debe64d6fbf31d23415f373adf47a7a034b7f0
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/governance refs/changes/10/330510/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: - repo: openstack/governance-uc

commit_message:
Remove Nodes._close_remotes() method

Remove the method Node._close_remotes() that was introduced in the
patch [1]. It cannot work correctly because there is
messed up logic management and hardware management layers.

This functionality should be resolved in a different way, from
logical layer (DevopsClient of fuel-qa code).

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/324389/

Change-Id: I6fcce11ce7545041a455919469137651e6011406
Related-Bug:#1597253

commit_message:
Add governance-uc repo

As per mailing list discussion[1], governance.openstack.org will
become a neutral place for all of OpenStack governance reference
information (Board, TC, UC).

This change adds a repository, governance-uc, which is to contain
the content for the UC component of governance.openstack.org, and
is step one of the 5 step plan:

- Create the repository (UC, infra)
- Populate it with the data you want there (UC)
- Work with infra to publish under /uc (UC, infra)
- Propose content for the neutral page (TC, UC)
- Change openstack/governance to publish under /tc,
  set up redirects/aliases (TC, infra)

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-tc/2016-June/001223.html

Change-Id: I80debe64d6fbf31d23415f373adf47a7a034b7f0
Needed-By: I941f2df200da0ac714f4afcf0c9d33d2711517d1

commit_message:
Add tenant id processing to segment plugin

We add tenant id processing to the segment service plugin.
The segment's tenant id must be equal to its network's
segment id.

By reading the segment's network, this patchset also closes
bug https://bugs.launchpad.net/neutron/+bug/1593402.

Change-Id: I19c75c2ff22e4810b30c8290b9c6b4a0bbb9e31d
Closes-Bug: #1593402

commit_message:
Take offline node device names into account in get_allocated_device_names

- get node device names from node xml

Change-Id: I9b2c6d75205c4f8ad22ee1c6d49f9a5885a76148
Closes-Bug: #1590419
Implements: blueprint fuel-devops-multiple-databases
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-devops refs/changes/05/333805/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def test_device_names_from_node(self): assert self.d.get_available_device_name('virnet') == 'virnet0' assert self.d.get_available_device_name('virnet') == 'virnet1' self.node = self.group.add_node( name='test_node', role='default', architecture='i686', hypervisor='test', ) self.interface = self.node.add_interface( label='eth0', l2_network_device_name='test_l2_net_dev', mac_address='64:b6:87:44:14:17', interface_model='virtio', ) self.interface = self.node.add_interface( label='eth1', l2_network_device_name='test_l2_net_dev', mac_address='64:b6:87:44:14:18', interface_model='virtio', ) self.node.define() assert self.d.get_allocated_device_names() == ['virnet2', 'virnet3'] assert self.d.get_available_device_name('virnet') == 'virnet4' assert self.d.get_available_device_name('virnet') == 'virnet5'

commit_message:
Add test for mcollective package version

Scenario:
1. Check mcollective version on bootstrap
2. Create cluster
3. Add one node to cluster
4. Provision nodes
5. Check mcollective version on node

Change-Id: I92fe35d0c31f08bd0d69a8993c9f3a72e2bdb60d
Closes-Bug: #1460073
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-qa refs/changes/22/336422/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: @logwrap def check_package_version(ip, package_name, expected_version, condition='ge'): """Check that package version equal/not equal/greater/less than expected :param ip: ip :param package_name: package name to check :param expected_version: expected version of package :param condition: predicate can be on of eq, ne, lt, le, ge, gt :return None: or raise UnexpectedExitCode """ cmd = "dpkg -s {0} " \ "| awk -F': ' '/Version/ {{print \$2}}'".format(package_name) logger.debug(cmd) result = ssh_manager.execute_on_remote( ip, cmd=cmd, assert_ec_equal=[0] ) version = result['stdout_str'] logger.info('{} ver is {}'.format(package_name, version)) err_msg = 'Package {} version is {} and not {} {}'.format(package_name, version, condition, expected_version) cmd = 'dpkg --compare-versions {0} {1} {2}'.format(version, condition, expected_version) ssh_manager.execute_on_remote(ip, cmd, assert_ec_equal=[0], err_msg = err_msg)

commit_message:
Use class structure for equipment.js lib

Refactoring equipment.js library to use "class" structure instead of "function"
+ minor changes in variables
+ fix "Warning: Expected to return a value at the end of this function"

Change-Id: Ib74bb2887dd0cf285a47c770321828336b5d9a48

commit_message:
Replace 'baremetal' with 'hybrid' doc for YAML template

- baremetal_example.yaml.rst replaced with already working template
  for hybrid environment and additional details
- add a known issue for fuel-devops3.0 with libvirt1.2.2 : network
  interface names on nodes can conflict between different
  environments.

Change-Id: I79d3e54a7d2ef19dd510933f62b871829cf291fa
blueprint: devops-bare-metal-driver
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-devops refs/changes/56/322156/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. _hybrid_example.yaml: Hybrid YAML template ====================baremetal lab to the Internet). Requirements to use the template with the baremetal lab: 1. If 'parent_iface' is used for any of libvirt l2_network_device, 'sudo' access on the host is required to automatic connect host's interfaces to libvirt virtual networks (linux bridges). 2. Export necessary environment variables: .. code-block:: bash - ENV_NAME - ISO_PATH - BAREMETAL_ADMIN_IFACE # Interface of the host, that has untagged # connectivity to the baremetal PXE network # and other tagged baremetal networks. # It should be in UP state. - IPMI_HOST{1..5}, IPMI_USER, IPMI_PASSWORD # Access credentials # to IPMI nodes 3. Configure MACs for *all* interfaces. In this template, order of the interfaces doesn't matter, because mapping OpenStack networks on node interfaces will be done using specified MAC addresses. So if a server has 4 network interfaces, but you planned to use only 2 interfaces for OpenStack networks, you can configure here only these 2 interfaces. 4. Use this template to create the environment: - From command line: .. code-block:: bash $ dos.py create-env ./path/to/hybrid_template.yaml - For already existing system tests (TEST_GROUP='smoke_neutron' for example) (requires fuel-qa branch > stable/mitaka, with support for fuel-devops3.0) .. code-block:: bash $ export DEVOPS_SETTINGS_TEMPLATE=./path/to/hybrid_template.yaml $ sh -x "utils/jenkins/system_tests.sh" \ -t test \ -w "${WORKSPACE}" \ -V "${VENV_PATH}" \ -j "${JOB_NAME}" \ -o --group="${TEST_GROUP}" \ -i "${ISO_PATH}" - For fuel-qa/fuel_tests (pytest-based): - In the test class, initialize self.config_file=./path/to/hybrid_template.yaml - Use @pytest.mark.need_ready_cluster for test case methods to load the config and prepare the environment. Additional details about this template: - 'public' l2_network_device in the libvirt group is used for providing NAT from baremetal tagged public network to the Internet, and for access to public IPs on the baremetal nodes directly from system tests. - Despite the fact that there is used two node groups, all baremetal nodes actually are connected to the PXE admin network of the first node group and will be bootstrapped as the nodes of the first node group. Second node group will not be used with this config, because it requires another network setup and manual Fuel configuration for additional interfaces. vlan_start: 0 vlan_start: 200 vlan_start: 201 vlan_start: 202 fuelweb_admin-pool02: net: *pool_default params: vlan_start: 0 public-pool02: net: *pool_default params: vlan_start: 200 storage-pool02: net: *pool_default params: vlan_start: 201 management-pool02: net: *pool_default params: vlan_start: 202 private-pool02: net: *pool_default params: vlan_start: 960 name: devops.driver.libvirt - 200 tag: 200 iface1: - name: baremetal-rack01 driver: name: devops.driver.baremetal fuelweb_admin: fuelweb_admin-pool02 public: public-pool02 storage: storage-pool02 management: management-pool02 private: private-pool02 ipmi_user: !os_env IPMI_USER ipmi_password: !os_env IPMI_PASSWORD ipmi_host: !os_env IPMI_HOST1 mac_address: xx:xx:xx:xx:xx:xx mac_address: xx:xx:xx:xx:xx:xx ipmi_user: !os_env IPMI_USER ipmi_password: !os_env IPMI_PASSWORD ipmi_host: !os_env IPMI_HOST2 mac_address: xx:xx:xx:xx:xx:xx mac_address: xx:xx:xx:xx:xx:xx ipmi_user: !os_env IPMI_USER ipmi_password: !os_env IPMI_PASSWORD ipmi_host: !os_env IPMI_HOST3 mac_address: xx:xx:xx:xx:xx:xx mac_address: xx:xx:xx:xx:xx:xx ipmi_user: !os_env IPMI_USER ipmi_password: !os_env IPMI_PASSWORD ipmi_host: !os_env IPMI_HOST4 mac_address: xx:xx:xx:xx:xx:xx mac_address: xx:xx:xx:xx:xx:xx mac_address: xx:xx:xx:xx:xx:xx ipmi_user: !os_env IPMI_USER ipmi_password: !os_env IPMI_PASSWORD ipmi_host: !os_env IPMI_HOST5 mac_address: xx:xx:xx:xx:xx:xx mac_address: xx:xx:xx:xx:xx:xx mac_address: xx:xx:xx:xx:xx:xx
deleted_lines: .. _baremetal_example.yaml: Baremetal YAML template =======================baremetal lab to the Internet. This template, with correct IPMI credentials and sudo access on the host for `brctl` command, can be used for run most of fuel-qa system tests on a baremetal lab (requires the [1] merged to fuel-qa). - 'public' l2_network_device is used for providing NAT from baremetal public network to the Internet, and for access to the public IPs from system tests; [1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/292977/ vlan_start: 100 vlan_start: 101 vlan_start: 102 name: devops.driver.libvirt.libvirt_driver - 100 tag: 100 iface1 groups: - name: baremetal-rack-01 driver: name: devops.driver.baremetal.ipmi_driver fuelweb_admin: fuelweb_admin-pool01 public: public-pool01 storage: storage-pool01 management: management-pool01 private: private-pool01 ipmi_user: username1 ipmi_password: password1 ipmi_host: ipmi1.test.local impi_cmd: ipmitool mac: aa:bb:cc:dd:ee:11 mac: aa:bb:cc:dd:ee:12 ipmi_user: username2 ipmi_password: password2 ipmi_host: ipmi2.test.local impi_cmd: ipmitool mac: aa:bb:cc:dd:ee:21 mac: aa:bb:cc:dd:ee:22 ipmi_user: username3 ipmi_password: password3 ipmi_host: ipmi3.test.local impi_cmd: ipmitool mac: aa:bb:cc:dd:ee:31 mac: aa:bb:cc:dd:ee:32 ipmi_user: username4 ipmi_password: password4 ipmi_host: ipmi4.test.local impi_cmd: ipmitool mac: aa:bb:cc:dd:ee:41 - label: iface2 mac: aa:bb:cc:dd:ee:42 mac: aa:bb:cc:dd:ee:43 mac: aa:bb:cc:dd:ee:44 iface2: iface4: ipmi_user: username5 ipmi_password: password5 ipmi_host: ipmi5.test.local impi_cmd: ipmitool mac: aa:bb:cc:dd:ee:51 - label: iface2 mac: aa:bb:cc:dd:ee:52 mac: aa:bb:cc:dd:ee:53 mac: aa:bb:cc:dd:ee:54 iface2: iface4:

commit_message:
Add action context to all action executions

Saved and asynchronous action executions have a partial context
with only callback URL and the action execution ID, and other
fields set to None. Non-saved synchronous action executions have
a context with all fields set to None.

Closes-Bug: #1596430
Change-Id: I88c572ddc665e97eefc057e108b1a06d3caecbdd
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/mistral refs/changes/15/334315/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def _create_action_execution(self, input_dict, runtime_ctx, desc='', action_ex_id=None): if action_ex_id is None: action_ex_id = utils.generate_unicode_uuid() # Assign the action execution ID here to minimize database calls. # Otherwise, the input property of the action execution DB object needs # to be updated with the action execution ID after the action execution # DB object is created. action_ex_id = utils.generate_unicode_uuid() self._insert_action_context(action_ex_id, input_dict) desc=desc, action_ex_id=action_ex_id # Assign the action execution ID here to minimize database calls. # Otherwise, the input property of the action execution DB object needs # to be updated with the action execution ID after the action execution # DB object is created. action_ex_id = utils.generate_unicode_uuid() self._insert_action_context(action_ex_id, input_dict, save=save) if save: self._create_action_execution( input_dict, runtime_ctx, desc=desc, action_ex_id=action_ex_id ) def _insert_action_context(self, action_ex_id, input_dict, save=True): """Template method to prepare action context. It insert the action context in the input if required runtime context. """ # we need to push action context to all actions. It's related to # https://blueprints.launchpad.net/mistral/+spec/mistral-custom-actions-api has_action_context = a_m.has_action_context( self.action_def.action_class, self.action_def.attributes or {} ) if has_action_context: input_dict.update( a_m.get_action_context(self.task_ex, action_ex_id, save=save) )
